HEADLINE: Midtown's Biggest Fans May Be Foreign Buyers

BYLINE: By AMY CORTESE

 BODY:
FOR many of New York's real estate players, Labor Day weekend was not the usual end-of-summer respite. The subprime mortgage woes had spread from the residential market to other areas, freezing credit, prompting layoffs at financial companies and threatening to derail the highflying Manhattan commercial market. 
 The extent of the damage -- which stemmed from years of easy credit extended to high-risk, or subprime, borrowers -- will become clearer as the market shakes out in coming months. But there is some reason for optimism: The credit crunch is likely to bring a much-needed break for an overheated market. What's more, it paves the way for a new class of deep-pocketed investors who have, until recently, watched the action from the sidelines.
 In particular, foreign investors who, buoyed by the strong economies and currencies in their own countries, now see an opportunity to scoop up coveted Manhattan real estate. 
 ''The global capital markets are flush with strong currency buyers who see our shores as a relative bargain,'' said Douglas Harmon, the senior managing director at Eastdil Secured, a real estate investment bank based in New York. 
 Foreign investors, according to Mr. Harmon and others in the industry, are generally more conservative in their financing, putting up more cash and relying less on debt. They also tend to be longer-term investors. By contrast, big domestic buyers, including the Blackstone Group, Tishman Speyer and Harry Macklowe, have used heavy levels of debt -- up to 95 percent of the purchase price, in some cases -- and relied on a steep increase in real estate prices and rents to justify the deals. 
 Foreign investment has picked up sharply. In May, there was the $1.18 billion sale of the Deutsche Bank building at 60 Wall Street to the Paramount Group of Germany. 
 In June, the Italian real estate investor Luigi Zunino made a foray into the New York market with the purchase of 660 Madison Avenue, the stylish office tower atop Barneys New York, for $375 million. At $1,488 a square foot, according to Mr. Harmon, it set a record for Manhattan commercial real estate. The deal, which closed on Aug. 30, was leveraged at a more modest 70 percent, with Deutsche Bank providing the financing, according to Mr. Harmon, who was the exclusive adviser for the transaction. That record was broken just four weeks later, when Somerset Partners, backed by European investors, paid $510 million -- or just under $1,600 a square foot -- for a 33-story office tower at 450 Park Avenue, according to Mr. Harmon, who also advised that deal. Somerset Partners assumed an existing commercial mortgage-backed security loan of $175 million, and used its own equity for the balance. 
 Israeli investors were also active. An Israeli-led investor group paid $648 million for a 70 percent stake in the Lipstick Building, Philip Johnson's landmark at 885 Third Avenue near 53rd Street. And Africa Israel USA, a subsidiary of an Israel-based international holding and investment company, bought the former headquarters of The New York Times Company on West 43rd Street from Tishman Speyer for $525 million, three times the $175 million that Tishman Speyer paid in November 2004. Africa Israel also bought the Clock Tower building in Madison Square Park for $200 million and a portion of the Apthorp Apartments on the Upper West Side for $426 million. 
 In late August, the Dubai investment company Istithmar beat out the Fast Retailing Company, the Asian apparel retailer, with a $942.3 million bid for Barneys New York, being sold by Jones New York.
 All told, there were 46 transactions totaling $5.27 billion by foreign buyers of commercial real estate in Manhattan through August, up from 28 for all of 2006, according to Real Capital Analytics in New York. ''The global economic expansion is creating a tremendous amount of surplus capital,'' said Dan Fasulo, a managing director of Real Capital Analytics, which tracks real estate deals. Much of that capital, he said, ''wants and needs to be here.''
 The United States is considered one of the most transparent and stable markets in the world, even given the current credit shakeup, with Midtown Manhattan, in particular, long an attraction for foreign buyers.
 ''People want a core, stable place to put their money,'' said Stephen Collins, the managing director of Jones Lang LaSalle's international capital group in the company's Washington office.
 Real estate professionals agree that the underlying fundamentals of the New York commercial market are still strong. Vacancy rates are near historic lows, at 5.3 percent, according to Cushman & Wakefield, with limited supply and development potential in prime locations. And while Manhattan rents have become painfully high for many businesses, they still lag behind those of several of the world's major cities, like London, Tokyo and Hong Kong. In London, for example, office space downtown can rent for as much as $:140 a square foot, or roughly $270. The average price per square foot in the West End of London by the end of the second quarter was $243, versus $79.85 a square foot for Midtown Manhattan, according to CB Richard Ellis.
 ''Foreign investors continue to view New York as a prime investment site, credit crunch or no credit crunch,'' said Bruce S. Schonbraun, the managing partner of the Schonbraun McCann Group, a real estate consulting firm based in New York.
 Then there is the psychological element of owning a storied property. ''It's the Monopoly board,'' said R. Stuart Gross, the executive managing director at Eastern Consolidated, a real estate investment services company in New York. ''Some of that mentality prevails.'' 
 Real estate professionals expect continuing increases in the most desirable New York City neighborhoods, especially Midtown Manhattan, though there is increased concern that a credit-related downturn in the financial sector could hurt the New York economy. Layoffs at financial services companies spiked nationwide in August, with more than 10,000 job cuts announced in the New York and New Jersey region alone, according to Challenger, Gray & Christmas, the executive employment firm. 
 Still, foreign investors are gearing up for their New York moment. Mr. Collins of Jones Lang LaSalle said that he and his colleagues spent much of August fielding calls from Irish, German and Japanese investors interested in American real estate. ''At the end of the day, it's still New York, the financial capital of the world,'' he said. ''With supply constrained, we will see some continued run-up'' of prices. 
 Matt M. Bronfman, a managing director at Jamestown Properties, a real estate company based in Atlanta that raises money from German investors, said he also saw ''more opportunities for guys like us who are going to put plenty of cash into deals and weren't relying on 95 percent debt.'' 
 ''We still love the New York story,'' he said.

HEADLINE: For Mexican Trucks, a Road Into the U.S.

BYLINE: By GRETEL C. KOVACH

DATELINE: DALLAS, Sept. 8 

 BODY:
Mexican truckers are expected to begin transporting goods throughout the United States in coming days, after a decision Thursday night by the Transportation Department that provisionally lifted restrictions confining them to the border region.
 The provision opening the United States to Mexican long-haul trucking was called for under the 1994 North American Free Trade Agreement, but it was delayed by resistance from some trucking and environmental groups.
 Under a one-year pilot program, as many as 100 Mexican trucking companies vetted by the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration at the Department of Transportation will be allowed to travel beyond the 25-mile commercial border zone. The program also clears American truckers to operate anywhere in Mexico for the first time. 
 Federal officials and some trucking and commerce representatives said the agreement would streamline cross-border trade, reduce pollution and lower prices for consumers. Under the current system, three trucks are usually required to transport one load of goods from either the United States or Mexico through the border region and onward to the final destination.
 ''This long-awaited project will protect public safety on American highways as we work to both save consumers money and help our economy,'' John Hill, head of the Motor Carrier Safety Administration, said in a statement.
 The first two companies cleared to participate in the program are Transportes Olympic, based in Nuevo Leon, near Monterrey, Mexico, and Stagecoach Cartage and Distribution, of El Paso, Tex. 
 The Teamsters, the Sierra Club and other groups said they would continue their legal fight to stop the program because of ''serious safety, environmental, smuggling and security concerns.''
 Leslie Miller, a spokeswoman for the Teamsters, said American truckers were most concerned about sharing the roads with potentially unsafe Mexican vehicles, not the potential of increased competition from lower-wage workers. ''We have nothing against Mexican truck drivers; it's the companies that exploit them that we oppose,'' she said. ''We're absolutely not ready for this.'' 
 A federal appeals court had rejected an emergency motion the groups filed to stop the program. On Friday, the Owner-Operator Independent Drivers Association also petitioned for further review of the program.
 But not all trucking interests oppose the program. A spokesman for the American Trucking Associations, a national group representing trucking companies, said they had concern over safety standards but thought over all that critics of the program were ''exaggerating the dangers.''
 ''They will inspect every Mexican truck every time it goes across the border, which is more than they do for American trucks,'' said the spokesman, Clayton Boyce.
 An inspector general's report released Thursday cleared the program to proceed but said the federal motor carrier safety agency had not completed plans for checking ''every truck, every time'' they cross the border as planned. The report also cited concern about state enforcement officials' testing English proficiency among the drivers, which is required under the pilot program.
 In recent years, Mexican trucks crossing the border with the United States were no more likely to be taken out of service because of safety or other violations than American trucks, according to preliminary results of a review of thousands of Texas Department of Public Safety inspection reports. The review was conducted by the Center for Transportation Research at the University of Texas, Austin.
 ''The problem on the interstates is too many trucks,'' said Robert Harrison, deputy director of the center, ''not too many Mexican trucks. As long as the inspections are adequate and in force, we have little to fear.''
 In 2006, more than 3.2 million trucks crossed the Mexican border through Texas, more than double the number that passed through California and other states, according to the federal Bureau of Transportation Statistics. 
 Trade with Mexico has quadrupled under Nafta, to $332 billion in 2006 from $81 billion in 1993, according to the United States Chamber of Commerce.
 ''This pilot project is a long overdue step toward reducing congestion and air pollution at the U.S.-Mexico border while promoting growth and jobs,'' Thomas J. Donohue, president of the chamber, said in a statement. ''The United States promised under Nafta to open its border to Mexican trucks -- with full reciprocity for U.S. carriers -- and it's time we kept our word.''

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths FOGEL, ENID M.

 BODY:
 FOGEL--Enid M., retired associate dean of students at the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business, died Sunday, September 2, at the University of Chicago Medical Center. Mrs. Fogel, 84, was a resident of Chicago's Hyde Park neighborhood. 
Her husband, Nobel Prizewinning economist Robert W. Fogel, credited her work as a researcher in helping him succeed in his career. Robert Fogel is the Charles R. Walgreen Distinguished Service Professor of American Institutions at the Graduate School of Business. At the time of her death, Mrs. Fogel and her husband were writing two books: ''Simon Kuznets and the Empirical Tradition in Economics'' and ''The Transformation of Economics, 1914-1980: Interviews with Economists.'' ''Over the years, Enid has been both my most confident supporter and my keenest critic,'' Robert Fogel wrote in his autobiography posted on the Nobel Prize web site (www.nobel prize.org). In addition to her husband, survivors include sons Michael and Steven; daughter - in - law Suzanne; grandchildren Lisa, Andrew, and Rachel; brother Ned Morgan; and sister Marjorie Henry. She was preceded in death by a sister, Ismay Flynn. A Memorial Service will be scheduled for the fall. In lieu of flowers, the family encourages friends to make donations to the University of Chicago or a charity of their choosing. Letters of condolence should be sent care of: Center for Population Economics, The University of Chicago Graduate School of Business, 5807 South Woodlawn Avenue, Chicago, IL 60637.

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths MAHONEY, BROOKE W

 BODY:
 MAHONEY--Brooke W. Died September 7th, 2007. The board and staff of the Volunteer Consulting Group/ boardnetUSA (VCG) express their profound sorrow on the loss of their esteemed founder and executive director. Ms. Mahoney served as ED of VCG since its founding in 1969. A graduate of Sayville High School, Ms. Mahoney received her bachelors degree from Randolph-Macon Women's College before attending Stanford Business School and earning an MBA from Harvard. She was a pioneer in the field of nonprofit governance and led the creation of www.boardnetUSA.org a web platform for non profit boards and candidates to find one another. She had been a Director of the Alliance for Nonprofit Management, the American Center for International Leadership, the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York, Brain Mapping Center at UCLA, Executive Women In Human Services, the Rauch Foundation. 
She also was a panelist with the National Endowment for the Arts, a member of the Economic Club of New York, published in the Harvard Business Review, chosen to be a Fellow at the Salzburg Institute, a member of the International Women's Forum, a Regional Finalist for a White House Fellowship and served on the Executive Council of the Harvard Business School. Ms. Mahoney was the daughter of the late Jesse Waring Mahoney, M.D. and Mary Watkins Reeves. Ms. Mahoney is survived by her husband Norman Berman, her stepchildren Alisa Berman and Jonathan Berman, stepgrandchildren Rachel and Jennefer Berman and William and Charles Slattery, her sister Lisa Reeves Mahoney M.D., her brothers Jesse Waring Mahoney, Jr. and Reeves Watkins Mahoney, Esq. and her nephews Rex Whitt Mahoney and Luke Reeves Mahoney. A memorial celebration is being planned for the late Fall. 
 MAHONEY--Brooke. The Women's Forum records with sorrow the death of Brooke Mahoney, a long time member and a women of extraordinary accomplishment. Her passion and vision will sustain all who loved and admired her. Deepest sympathy is extended to her family, friends and colleagues at Volunteer Consulting Group. Westina Matthews Shatteen, President

HEADLINE: Putting a Price on the Priceless: One Life

BYLINE: By BILL MARSH

 BODY:
ASSIGNING a dollar value to a person's life might seem impossible, not to mention unthinkable. But after a wrongful death, the needs of the surviving family - financial, emotional or both - often lead to that grim calculation.
 Forensic economists advise courts and governments on how to translate lives cut short into money for the living. 
 ''It's terribly distressing to anyone who gets involved with it,'' said Don Frankenfeld, a South Dakota forensic economist who helped determine compensation for Sept. 11 victims. ''It's a scary, ghoulish kind of arithmetic.''
 Six years after the attacks, experts are still being asked to calculate the value of lives lost. There were 95 lawsuits by survivors bypassing the official compensation fund in favor of the courts. About half of them have settled; 41 cases are pending, including some concerning injuries. They are set to go to trial in federal court on Sept. 24.
 Here is how some economists, along with the American military, have arrived at dollar values to compensate for the loss of individual lives.
 The Value of Earnings Lost, Plus a Common Sum for Suffering
 THE fund to compensate families of those killed on 9/11 paid about $2 million, on average, for each of the 2,280 dead. The fund used three measures to set payments:
 1. Economic loss.
 2. Set amounts for pain and suffering: $250,000, plus $100,000 for each surviving spouse and child.
 3. Subtract any life insurance paid.
 Last, the fund's special master, Kenneth R. Feinberg, had discretionary power to adjust payouts, often adding to the awards for low-income applicants and subracting from the high end.
 Mr. Feinberg, a Washington lawyer, said the government's generosity was unlikely to be repeated.
 ''I believe the 9/11 fund is not a precedent for anything,'' he said. ''How do you justify giving $2 million, on average, to 9/11 victims and nothing to victims in Oklahoma City? Nothing to Katrina victims? It was a very emotional Congressional response to an unprecedented historical event.''
 Mr. Feinberg is now directing a privately backed fund for victims of the shootings at Virginia Tech in April. Families of the 32 killed will be eligible for a uniform sum: $180,000.
 The Value of Experience Lost
 THERE is economic damage from a wrongful death: the value of a person's lost work life.
 Then there is the loss of life's experience - the daily satisfaction of living. Presumably, says the Chicago economist Stan V. Smith, people cherish life itself much more than their work.
 ''We value our being far more than we value our doing,'' he said. So why give the loss of work a dollar value but not the loss of daily experience?
 Mr. Smith has tried. He coined the term ''hedonic damages'' for lives and experiences lost.
 ''As economists, we can't say there's a limit to the value of life,'' he said. ''But there may be an average value that juries can consider.''
 That average, Mr. Smith figures, is around $4 million.
 Mr. Smith says that people unknowingly set a value on their own lives by what they are willing to pay to reduce their everyday risk of death.
 Say a certain home safety feature costs $50. If research shows that for every 100,000 of those devices in use, one life is saved, then the implied value of that life is $5 million:
 100,000 devices x $50 = $5,000,000 to save 1 life
 The more people are willing to pay for safety features, the more they are implicitly valuing their lives. Mr. Smith has calculated value-of-life figures for numerous purchases, based on their costs and how much they reduce the risk of death.
 PURCHASED ITEMS AND IMPLIED VALUE OF ONE LIFE:
 Automotive air bags: $598,463
 Smoke detectors: $628,618
 Auto safety features: $4,198,517
 Top-grade tires: $6,031,019
 The law creating the Sept. 11 fund provided for hedonic damages. But while common in injury cases, so far few states recognize it as a consideration in wrongful-death cases. Critics scoff at the notion of putting a dollar amount on enjoyment of life, calling it a costly ploy to inflate damage awards.
 The Military's Method
 ON Feb. 1, an American soldier - who was married with three children - was killed in Iraq. The benefits to this serviceman's family, depending on how long each member lives and whether he or she goes on to college, could amount to about $1.9 million over their lifetimes. (That figure is in today's dollars. The face value of the money would grow over time, to allow for the effects of inflation and keep its purchasing power from eroding.) Military families face a complicated death-benefits structure that evolves as children grow up and spouses retire or remarry. Bradley J. Snyder, the emeritus president of Armed Forces Services Corporation, which advises families, urges them to use benefits counseling provided by the military to avoid losing money owed to them. Mr. Snyder calculated the benefits to this soldier's wife and children:
 LUMP SUMS:
 Social Security death benefit: $255
 Military death gratuity: $100,000
 Military life insurance: $400,000
 TOTAL: $500,255
 POTENTIAL MONEY FOR COLLEGE 
 (paid while they attend): $199,602
 SOCIAL SECURITY, SURVIVOR BENEFITS 
 (total over lifetimes): $1.24 million
 This assumes his wife will live to age 80. The annual benefit will start at $62,808, but decline to $12,804 after the children reach 18. When she is 62, it will rise to $23,904.
 The soldier's base pay had been about $36,000 a year.

LENGTH: 612 words

HEADLINE: New Jersey's Shame

 BODY:
The rich get richer and the poor stay poor. The sad adage presents itself dramatically in New Jersey. 
 Contrast any of New Jersey's major cities with their nearby suburbs and the difference is startling -- modest or deteriorating housing downtown, sprawling mansions and obvious wealth beyond the city limits. 
 The latest census figures tell the same story in dry arithmetic. The wealthiest 20 percent of residents in Essex County, where Newark is, have incomes almost 23 times as high as the poorest 20 percent. In most other New Jersey counties, the gap ranges between 15 and 20 times as high. 
 The reasons for this disparity are well-known: well-paying manufacturing jobs have disappeared, replaced by low-paying jobs filled in many cases by immigrants, like landscaping or working in fast food establishments. Meanwhile, at the upper end of the scale, Wall Street bonuses have sent the averages skyward. 
 How to bridge the income gap is less obvious. According to the census figures, 677,000 New Jersey residents, or 7.8 percent of the population, lived below the national poverty line in 2005-6, almost the same as during 2000-1. Poverty for children was worse -- 11.5 percent. And these figures fail to show the problem's real extent since the poverty level is defined the same throughout the continental United States: $20,650 for a family of four. That is unrealistically low for New Jersey. 
 ''We hope that people are moving up the ladder, but we really don't know,'' says James Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers.
 To its credit, New Jersey is helping by pouring money into its poorer schools. A string of State Supreme Court decisions has forced Trenton to spend about as much money on schools in several of its poorest districts as is spent in wealthier districts. The hope is that with better education, these students will do better in the job market than their parents have done. 
 With the state facing a fiscal crisis, there is increased pressure to reduce the commitment to poor districts. That must not happen. While the formula for state aid should be adjusted according to districts that need help the most, a state like New Jersey, with the second highest median income in the nation, has a moral obligation to see that all students get a solid education. 
 There is an important role for the federal government too. It must expand a program providing health insurance for children whose families cannot afford coverage. Regrettably, President Bush has threatened to veto a bill that would make almost half of New Jersey's 100,000 uninsured children eligible for coverage. 
 The Bush administration has already changed the rules to make it almost impossible to enroll children above 250 percent of the federal poverty level, or about $51,000 for a family of four. That may seem generous in states like Mississippi or Alabama, but it is far too low for New Jersey. Few families making that little can pay the high costs of rent and food in this area and still have enough left for the $11,000 or $12,000 a year that a typical family policy costs. 
 Bills approved in the House and Senate would provide coverage for children whose families earn up to three times the federal poverty level (the Senate bill) or four times (the House bill). A recent poll showed that almost two-thirds of adults support coverage for children at those levels. And in New Jersey, it is hardly too high. 
 In the interest of children, in the interest of simple economic realism, and in the interest of compensating in some small way for New Jersey's yawning income gap, President Bush should sign the final measure. 

CORRECTION-DATE: September 16, 2007

 CORRECTION:
Editorials on children's health, on Aug. 26, and on economic disparities, in the New Jersey Section on Sept. 9, incorrectly described a bill approved by the House of Representatives for the State Children's Health Insurance Program. The Bill does not contain a provision raising eligibility to four times the poverty level.

PERSON: GEORGE W BUSH (50%)

My Many Years Of Saying 'Goodnight'
 To the Editor:
 ''Goodnight New York,'' the Sept. 2 photographic essay celebrating the 60th anniversary of the publication of ''Goodnight Moon,'' brought back many memories, mostly good: reading the book to my children, then later to my grandchildren. 
 Five years ago, trying to hold back the tears as my husband was drifting away from Alzheimer's, I read it to him every night. 
 He liked it as much as the children had. 
 Mary-Ellen Siegel Upper West Side
 Forced Out of New York by High Housing Prices
 To the Editor:
 Re ''City of Aspiration'' (Sept. 2), on the housing prospects for the middle class of New York: 
 My wife and I consider ourselves middle class, and we recently left the city. We were two professionals, licensed and practicing civil engineers. 
 We lived in a one-bedroom apartment in Manhattan and were O.K. financially. We then started a family and could not afford Manhattan anymore. 
 We looked at other options in the city, and even near suburbs, but we could not afford anything we saw and decided to move back home to Texas. 
 The article mentions a median-price house of $510,000 in the New York area and other home prices of $600,000, which this middle-class family could never afford. Our home close to town in Houston was half that, and we are just meeting the budget here. 
 Without the advantage of having relatives nearby (they are all here in Texas), we would have the added cost of day care or the limiting factor of one income. 
 So, while the tone of the article makes it seem as if there is affordable housing, after my personal search, I couldn't reach that same conclusion. 
 While I love New York, and we often miss the city terribly, we feel we had no choice but to leave. We were forced out by economics. 
 If only we had decided to be investment bankers. 
 Joel Barron Houston
 It's Time to Retire Those Carriage Horses
 To the Editor:
 New York City's horse-drawn carriage industry shouldn't be seen as a permanent fixture just needing cleanup. It's time to end the business entirely. Too many horses have endured misery in the name of entertainment. 
 The New York City comptroller's recent audit underscored the neglect and mistakes of a dysfunctional industry. May the audit awaken the mayor and City Council to the real heart of the matter: exploitation is not an appropriate tourist attraction. 
 Edita Birnkrant Upper West Side
 The writer is the New York City campaign coordinator, Friends of Animals.

HEADLINE: The New Gray Areas

BYLINE: By ANNA BERNASEK

 BODY:
Ever thought of retiring to someplace sunny and close to the beach? Or maybe you've considered moving into the city after raising a family in the suburbs. In fact, most of us will never do either. According to the United States Census Bureau, 9 out of 10 Americans over 60, or 41.5 million people, stayed in the same home or in the same county between 1995 and 2000. During that period, only 4.4 million Americans over 60 moved away. Those figures don't seem likely to change anytime soon. Last year, AARP surveyed Americans over 50 and found that 89 percent wanted to stay in their current home as long as possible. ''Americans are going to age in place,'' says Elinor Ginzler, AARP's director for livable communities. 
 William H. Frey, a demographer at the Brookings Institution in Washington, released a report in May called ''Mapping the Growth of Older America.'' Based on Census Bureau data and the bureau's and his own projections, Frey found that growth in the pre-senior population -- Americans 55 to 64 -- was a key factor in pinpointing where the senior population would take off in the next 15 or 20 years. Frey forecast that states in the West like Nevada and Utah and Southern states like Texas, Georgia and Florida would have almost two and a half times as many retirees in 2030 as they had in 2000. And he predicted that the suburbs of New York, Philadelphia, Chicago and Los Angeles would have much faster growth in their retirement populations than the cities they surround. Stephen M. Golant, a gerontologist at the University of Florida in Gainesville, has studied the effects of a booming retiree sector on local communities and found that up until age 75 or so, older residents tend to be strong economic contributors to communities, spending on entertainment, restaurants, housing and health and medical services and often continuing to work or volunteer. But as they get older and their health fails and savings begin to run down, that effect may start to turn negative. 
 Ultimately, experts on aging say the impact of the graying of America on our communities may depend on our ability to plan ahead for the needs of the elderly -- housing options, health care services, public transportation. Golant says, ''The key factor will be whether we have the willingness as a society to respond to groups that become vulnerable -- economically, physically and psychologically.''

HEADLINE: Inside the Upside-Down World of the Short Sale

BYLINE: By NOAM SCHEIBER

 BODY:
''I have a license to carry. It's only for dogs. I've had a couple of bad run-ins with dogs.'' This was Gary Prescott. A few weeks earlier, Prescott and his partners at a firm called Equity Solutions Realty bid on a property just north of St. Petersburg, Fla. The owners, a recently separated couple, were several months late on their mortgage payments. Prescott was hoping to buy it before the foreclosure. So on a broiling-hot afternoon in May, he and I and a woman named Rose, who came to appraise the property for the bank, stood before a two-toned, white and cherry red house with two ratty mattresses leaning against the facade. A dog started barking when Prescott opened the door, and Rose became concerned. ''Are these people O.K. with us coming in?'' Rose asked. ''Yeah, I met the lady this morning,'' Prescott said to her, but then he excused himself. Two minutes later he was back with a black Kel- Tec handgun. 
 Prescott keeps his handgun at the ready for precisely this ritual, known to real estate investors as the B.P.O., or broker price opinion, and to the rest of us as an appraisal. The bank relies on the appraiser to evaluate Prescott's offer. Prescott showed up on this day to plead his case.
 Prescott trooped to the rear of the house while Rose, who asked that her last name not be used, waited with me in the foyer. Prescott is a wide-faced man with earnest green eyes and a mild overbite, which, from certain angles, makes him look much younger than his 50 years. He first got into real estate in the 1980s while attending college in Vermont. Lacking money, he used elaborate financing schemes to build a portfolio of some 20 apartments, which he'd rent to fellow students. He carries himself like someone who knows his way around an investment property.
 ''It's O.K., the dog's in a pen,'' Prescott called out. Rose and I took this as a cue to wade cautiously into the living room. The house looked as if it had been abandoned and resettled by squatters. There were takeout boxes all over the floor, along with empty beer cans and bottles of vodka. The walls were streaked with grime, and the only thing masking the smell of mildew was a terrific pet odor. The house was fairly typical of an impending foreclosure, in other words. People who can't make their mortgage payments don't often make maintenance a high priority. The lawn is usually the first to go; the living space the last. This place had been empty for at least a month and looked to be in the final stages of decay.
 For the last few years, Prescott and his partners have done a booming business in a transaction called a short sale. When a homeowner gets behind on his payments, he normally has two alternatives to foreclosure: refinance, or sell the house and pay back the loan. But since the local market collapsed in late 2005, many mortgages have turned ''upside down''-- that is, the owner owes more than the house is currently worth -- eliminating both options. That's where Equity Solutions comes in. Prescott asks the bank to approve the sale of the house at a cut-rate price (hence, ''short sale'') and to forgive the balance of the mortgage, all prior to the actual foreclosure. When executed correctly, a short sale can leave everyone better off: the homeowner walks away with his credit largely intact; the bank salvages part of a nonperforming loan without the headache of repossessing a house; and, of course, Equity Solutions gets the best of the deal -- a property it hopes to flip at a profit. (The firm rehabs some houses before selling them; others it unloads ''as is,'' a practice known as wholesaling.)
 Rose and I both stopped short when we got to the back porch. Prescott had neglected to mention that the dog in question was actually two dogs -- and that both were pit bulls. He seemed untroubled by their presence, however, and promptly got to work. ''There's the roof,'' he said, pointing to an overhang jutting out over the porch. ''It's all warped, corroded.'' Rose nodded without comment. Prescott darted inside: ''I'll show you the baseboards,'' he said. ''You can see the termite damage.'' Another nod. ''Oh, this is worth a picture here. The dry wall is peeling off.''
 After a while, Rose stopped tiptoeing around the house as if it were booby-trapped. She snapped a couple of unsolicited photos and even led the way into a bedroom. When we came out, the door to the adjacent bedroom was shut, and Rose turned the knob to ease it open. Suddenly she darted past me toward the front door, arms flailing over her head cartoon-style. A third pit bull came trotting out behind her and into the yard. The dog was clearly pregnant -- her swollen stomach sagged almost to the floor -- but mercifully she was good-humored. The smell, though, was ferocious. I poked my head into the vacated room and found the floor covered in excrement.
 ''She's wagging her tail, she's fine,'' Prescott called soothingly. ''Thank God the dog has a good disposition. A lot of pregnant ones don't.'' He resumed his inventory. ''Have you seen the kitchen? God forbid you have snakes in there -- '' But Rose had had enough. ''This is definitely just a tear-down,'' she sighed.
 ''You notice when she came out she was very negative,'' Prescott told me as we drove off. He was pleased that the bank would be receiving a downbeat assessment. ''This one is probably better to wholesale, but it's a good house for us if not.''
 Prescott met his partner Jim Izzolo in late 1999. A few years earlier, Prescott moved to Florida as a marketing executive for a portraitstudio chain called Olan Mills. Izzolo, who is about a decade younger than Prescott, was the real estate agent who sold him his first house in the area. The two men hit it off and began working together on the occasional real estate deal. One early investment was a four-family building on the Gulf of Mexico, not far from St. Petersburg. Prescott and Izzolo renovated the place and rented it out at a hefty monthly rate. They bought other beach properties to rehab and resell.
 One night in 2002, Prescott was at a bar in an oceanside restaurant when he overheard an older man say he'd bought 43 houses all at once. Prescott was intrigued and took the man out to lunch the following day. It turned out his dining companion had purchased the properties through short sales. It was the first time Prescott had heard of anyone buying a house for less than the amount owed on the mortgage.
 When Prescott told his partner about the idea, Izzolo was skeptical. ''You can't do it,'' Izzolo said. But both men were curious enough to do a little research. Prescott asked around at his real estate investment club. Sure enough, a few had heard of short-buying, and one investor recommended some self-proclaimed gurus. Before long, Izzolo and Prescott were on a plane to Denver to attend a course taught by two of them -- Dwan Bent- Twyford and Sharon Restrepo. Together, it cost them $4,500 to enroll, plus $3,000 for airfare and hotel. Izzolo paid it grudgingly. ''If this is a bunch of fluff, I'm going to raise hell,'' he told Prescott.
 The seminar was convincing enough that the two men paid Restrepo $10,000 to help set up their business, then called G. R. Prescott & Associates. The business did well from the start, and earlier this year, Prescott and Izzolo moved into a new office in a small shopping center in Largo, a middle-class St. Petersburg suburb. During the boom, foreclosure was mostly something that affected low-income people. It made sense to be near south St. Petersburg, the city's poorest neighborhood. Since the crash began in late 2005, however, foreclosure problems have worked their way up the socioeconomic ladder. According to the most recent data from the Mortgage Bankers Association, the foreclosure rate for prime borrowers, who tend to be middle class, has increased by one-third since bottoming out in early 2006. And Prescott and Izzolo have followed the trends uptown. Prescott says that the potential for a large profit is greater reselling middle-class houses, with mortgages in the $150,000-to-$300,000 range, than for downscale homes.
 Still, as lucrative as it can be, short-buying more upscale homes can be tricky in a down market. Prescott says the partnership was closing deals on about 50 houses a year at a profit of about $20,000 to $25,000 each at the height of the boom. But last year, the first full year of focusing on more affluent homeowners, was the company's worst ever -- it made only about $10,000 to $15,000 a house on approximately the same number of houses. Reselling the homes has become much more difficult. During the boom, Prescott and Izzolo could buy a house and quickly wholesale it to another investor, who would do the fixing up and either rent it or resell it. But the slumping real estate market has scared off many investors. And while Equity Solutions can always do the rehab and sell the house retail -- that is, to a family that wants to live in it -- a down market tends to make middle-class buyers incredibly choosy. For example, the company recently negotiated the short sale of a house for $199,000, even though the owner still owed $288,000 on the mortgage. But the partners could resell the house for only $230,000. They made a profit of about $21,000 -- less than they expected. This has made it all the more important to procure homes at a substantial discount.
 In recent months, the parade of grim statistics on foreclosures -- more of a death march, really -- has become the central story line in this decade's preoccupation with real estate. The Wall Street Journal reported in June that lenders will repossess nearly one million homes through foreclosure both this year and next, almost double the annual number between 2000 and 2006. The problem with so many foreclosures is that they create a vicious cycle. When a bank repossesses a home, it tries to unload it as quickly as possible, for as cheap as necessary. This adds to the inventory of homes available -- in the Tampa Bay area, only about 1 in 15 homes sells each month, versus 1 in 2 at the market peak -- and depresses prices. But when prices drop, foreclosures rise, because financially strapped homeowners can't sell their houses to pay off their mortgages.
 The foreclosures are concentrated in the subprime portion of the market -- that is, among people who qualified for mortgages despite the fact that they had poor credit histories. Nationally, 1.3 percent of all homes were in foreclosure as of early 2007, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association, but that percentage quadruples for the subprime demographic. Subprime mortgages typically involve adjustable interest rates that escalate quickly, so it's not surprising that foreclosures have increased over the past few years. Since the real estate market peaked in 2005, the subprime foreclosure rate has spiked from 3.3 percent to more than 5 percent. Some of the mortgages, called ''liar loans,'' require almost no documentation of a borrower's ability to pay. The most infamous breed is known among mortgage brokers as the ''Ninja'' loan, short for ''no income, no job or assets.''
 All of this was made possible by the securitization of residential mortgages, one of the most fateful financial-market innovations of the last generation. Put simply, many lenders no longer hang on to the majority of the loans they make. Instead, they typically sell them to investment banks, which slice them up into securities and offload them to investors. Over the last several years, hedge funds, pension funds and university endowments eagerly snatched up subprime mortgage securities on the assumption that, even if a significant number of homeowners defaulted, the rest were paying such high interest rates that the investment was sound.
 The entirely foreseeable consequence of this was to give rise to what economists call ''moral hazard.'' Because the banks were acting as middlemen rather than holding the mortgages themselves, their incentive to vet borrowers declined strikingly. Mortgage quality declined with it. Over the last few months, as investors have seen the value of their subprime portfolios collapse -- two such funds run by the investment bank Bear Stearns disintegrated this summer, for example -- it has become painfully obvious that investors' assumptions about the risks they took on were wildly optimistic.
 One day I was in the Equity Solutions office and Prescott handed me a Washington Post article about New Century Financial, one of the more notorious mortgage lenders. The article reported that salesmen in one New Century office had become legendary for strolling past the cubicles of the company's appraisers -- the people charged with rejecting bad applications -- with a baseball bat. One salesman slammed his bat down on an appraiser's desk after she turned down a deal. ''The stress in that place was ungodly,'' the appraiser told The Post. ''There was instant notification to everyone as soon as you rejected a loan. And you dreaded doing it because you paid for it.''
 Long before there can be a short sale, even before there can be a broker price opinion, Prescott must locate a distressed homeowner and establish a rapport. Some in the short-sale business use fliers or direct mail for this purpose. Others cold-call. A select few advertise on radio or latenight television. But no one would deny that old-fashioned door-knocking is far and away the most effective way of landing a deal.
 Today the partners no longer personally do any prospecting. Instead, they employ a team of roughly half a dozen contractors to gin up business. The door-knockers receive a fixed fee of $3,000 for any deal that closes (and a bonus if the house is subsequently resold for a large profit). The more prolific among them can earn $75,000 a year. Four years ago, however, when Prescott and Izzolo were just starting out, it fell to the two men to do the door-knocking themselves. Izzolo was the undisputed champion of this activity, and he still trains the new recruits.
 Izzolo volunteered to take me through a brief role-playing exercise. He is a small man with short brown hair and droopy eyelids. The day I met him, he was wearing a short-sleeved red shirt and black chinos and sported a week-old goatee. Though he has a half-ironic manner that makes it hard to tell when he's joking, particularly when he slips into over-enunciated real estate speak, his talent for salesmanship is obvious.
 The basic idea, as in all sales efforts, is to leave the prospect simultaneously insecure about his situation and awed by your expertise. To accomplish the former, the door-knocker will systematically demolish any assumptions, most of them admittedly delusional, that allow the homeowner to believe he can resolve his troubles alone. To accomplish the latter, the door-knocker will trot out an intimidating litany of dates and deadlines -- you will get another notice in 30 days, you will have a chance to ask a judge for a 60-day extension -- which the door-knocker can help navigate.
 Izzolo illustrates one technique based on his own experience. ''You'd knock on a door and say, 'What do you think your house is worth?' They say, 'One-twenty.' You look around and say, 'One-twenty?' '' Izzolo screws up his face for emphasis. ''They say, 'Well, 110.' You say, 'One-ten?' '' Izzolo screws up his face again, but now he sticks out both hands, too. ''They say, 'O.K., 100.' You say, 'Well, you don't have any equity.' They think you're going to walk away. And you say, 'No, there's a way.' ''
 Door-knocking has become vastly more efficient in the Internet age. Banks and mortgage lenders must file paperwork with a local court to begin the foreclosure process, at which point the borrower typically has three to six months to settle up or vacate the house. Pre-Internet, anyone prospecting for short sales would have spent hours each week rifling through court documents. In recent years, however, online listing services have proliferated. The service-providers send workers to the courthouse and regularly update their listings. Investors like Prescott pay a monthly fee to access them. The prospectors then fan out across town to make their pitches.
 One afternoon I went on a door-knock with a prospector named Ray Smith. Smith is in his late 20s, broad-shouldered and blond. He bought a few houses from Prescott and his partners two years ago and came aboard not long after. Smith has recently scaled back his prospecting efforts while he studies to become a licensed appraiser and tends to his own fast-growing stable of rental units. He lives on the northern edge of St. Petersburg's slowly gentrifying ghetto, in strategic proximity to tenants and prospective clients.
 We circled the neighborhood in Smith's beat-up Jeep Cherokee for two hours without making much progress. When we rang the doorbell of a tan stucco house on 20th Avenue, two children pressed their heads against the window, but no one answered. A teenage girl greeted us at an apricotcolored house on 26th Avenue. She told us her mother received a thick package -- the foreclosure notice -- after the landlord stopped paying the mortgage, but she didn't know any more than that. Between houses, Smith shared his philosophy on door-knocking. ''Most people want to talk to you,'' he said. ''It'' -- foreclosure -- ''is a problem. And everyone wants to talk about their problems.'' Later he told me that the trick is to be patient. ''A lot of people think they have more options than they do,'' he said. ''They say they're going to sell it. You call back and say, 'Did you sell it yet?' '' Invariably the answer is no.
 The very last address on our list was not far from Smith's place. It was a two-story house with blue-gray siding, set back so far from the road we almost missed it. A makeshift wooden fence blocked our access to the porch, so Smith banged on the side of the building. When no one answered, we tried our luck at the rear of the house. Finally, a gawky man no older than 25 emerged from the porch. He had long brown hair and a prominent Adam's apple and was wearing a gray T-shirt that said, ''Makeup Doesn't Cure Ugly People.'' It looked as if we had woken him up.
 Once Smith introduced himself, the young man seemed either grateful for the interest or too defeated to shoo him away -- it wasn't entirely clear which. Predictably, the man said he was thinking about selling. ''What are you trying to sell it for?'' Smith asked. The young man said, ''Two-fifteen.'' Smith said: ''Two-fifteen? Wow, you really think you can sell it for 215?''
 After some brief chitchat, the young man invited us in for a tour. He told us he was a landscape foreman who had lost his job. He couldn't suppress his pride when showing off the fans he'd installed and a new second-floor bathroom. Behind almost every door there were more people, three generations in all. A mother in one room, a sister in another. Young children came out of the woodwork, as in one of those cartoons where a house has been sliced down the middle to reveal activity inside every nook and cranny. When the tour ended, Smith asked if there was a place we could sit and talk. The landscaper led us to a small den with a bookshelf full of James Patterson novels and an ashtray overflowing with cigarette butts.
 The landscaper told us his family moved into the house last fall, at which point the landlord suggested they buy it. In December he closed on a mortgage. He told me he thought the payments would be around $1,000 a month, but by February they were nearly double that amount. He lost his job around the same time. With no income and an entire brood to feed -- he and his girlfriend have five children, including 4-month-old twins -- he said he hadn't paid more than $100 in any month since. The foreclosure documents arrived in mid-May, about a week and a half before we did.
 Speaking very slowly and very calmly, Smith sketched a crude time line on a yellow legal pad with the dates June 17 and July 17 spelled out in block letters. ''You'll get another foreclosure notice here,'' he said, pointing to the second date. He told the landscaper he would have a month to move out at that point, unless he got an extension from a judge. ''We'll go to court with you,'' he added reassuringly. Smith punctuated his sentences by asking, ''Do you see what I'm saying?'' The landscaper nodded vigorously each time, but it wasn't clear that he did. Every few minutes he looked up and said hopefully, ''If you could help us stay in the house, that'd be great,'' even though Smith had suggested nothing of the kind. After Smith explained how a short sale works, he handed the landscaper a document authorizing Prescott to access his records. ''Now let's do the right thing and sign there,'' Smith said. The young man scribbled his signature.
 After the encounter with the landscaper, I stopped by the office to meet with Izzolo and Bill Mirro, a childhood friend of Izzolo's who joined the firm almost three years ago. They immediately concluded that the landscaper's mortgage was dubious. For one thing, the property had been appraised for $215,000. But given the size of the house and its location -- on the northern edge of the poorest part of town -- the price seemed outrageously high. All the more so given that the sale took place in December 2006, a year after the market had turned. Appraisers must justify their estimates with recent sales data for comparable houses in the neighborhood. Mirro speculated that the appraiser had simply gone two blocks north -- across Central Avenue, the boundary between the historically white and black sections of St. Petersburg -- where an identical house sells for $20,000 to $30,000 more. ''If the bank's based in California, they don't know,'' he said.
 The landscaper appeared to have what is known as a ''phantom second'' mortgage. Because he lacked money for a down payment and had no hope of qualifying for 100 percent financing on $193,500, which is what the owner appears to have been asking, the inflated appraisal of $215,000 made it look as if he were borrowing only 90 percent of the asking price. It was unlikely that the landscaper even knew about the arrangement.
 The landscaper never actually owned his house in any meaningful sense. He never could have afforded it in a rational world. ''It was the bank's house,'' Mirro said. ''He was just living in it.'' From the perspective of the lender, he was an easy mark for a mortgage that could quickly be resold on Wall Street, but he had no equity. The real casualties of the boom are people like Shenecial Bailey and her husband, who owned the house with the pregnant pit bull. If not for relentless marketing and the allure of easy money, she would probably be sitting on more than $50,000 in home equity today.
 The couple bought their house in 1998 for the modest sum of $53,000. By 2003, the value had climbed to more than $70,000. Soon they were on the receiving end of endless offers to cash out their equity in exchange for a larger loan. They agreed to one in February of that year, then again in December 2005. This put another $45,000 in their pockets. But by the following year, the money was gone and the Baileys were splitting up. The monthly payments were now more than double what they had been under the original mortgage, and far higher than Shenecial Bailey, an assistant manager at a local McDonald's, could afford. She stopped making payments in August, and the bank sent a foreclosure notice in December.
 By late April, Bailey was about to lose not only her home but also her shot at ever getting another one. Prescott hadn't heard from the Baileys' lender for several days, and the auction date was less than a week away. If it were to arrive before Prescott could close the deal, the Baileys would see their credit destroyed and all his work would be for naught. Prescott advised Shenecial Bailey to declare Chapter 13 bankruptcy to stop a potential sale. He had a paralegal prepare the necessary documents and urged Bailey to drive the documents to the courthouse immediately. It was the morning of the auction, and it sometimes takes the court two days to notify a lender of a bankruptcy filing. She and Prescott just had to hope the papers would be processed in time.
 Prescott is prone to philosophical musings, which sometimes masquerade as mundane observations. One day, as we were driving back from one of his properties, he explained his approach to his volatile line of work. ''The key to this business is to keep expenses low,'' he told me. ''That's where all these seminars go wrong. They say buy a nice car, buy a nice house. All those people lose.'' He was scowling as he told me this.
 Even now that he has socked away a comfortable nest egg, Prescott still lives modestly. His dream is to buy the lot next door to his house and build a Mediterranean-style palazzo. But he plans to do it in the style of the third world. ''I'll put the facade up, build the whole shell, do the grounds, build the foyer, a bedroom to start off. But then you leave it and do it out of your own pocket.'' It's as though Prescott has seen too much wreckage as an investor to take on even a modest risk in his personal life. In any case, he says he's too cheap to consider it. ''Even at a decent interest rate, if you financed it for 30 years and borrowed $2 million, you'd end up paying $4 million, $4.5 million. That's nuts. Crazy.''
 Dealing day in and day out with foreclosure candidates can influence your worldview. Prescott's experiences have made him a bit of a bleeding heart, even if he wouldn't necessarily describe himself that way. ''The socialization process you get in this country is not good,'' he said as we drove farther. ''We're consumers, we're not people. People go through school and it's rote learning. They're not equipped to function in society.''
 Prescott is the first to acknowledge that he's in business to make a buck. But his self-image is deeply tied to the idea that he's helping homeowners. He often gets emotionally involved in their cases. When Izzolo mentioned a client named Harold Craton, 79, who started drowning financially after his furniture-refinishing business failed, Prescott became sober-faced. ''This is a guy you'd really like to see keep the house, but he's so far under the bus.'' Another client was a 21-year-old telemarketer whose uncle had used him as a frontman to secure several mortgages, then had promptly fallen behind on the payments. ''Whoever made those loans ought to be in jail,'' Prescott told me. ''Here's a kid working hard, trying to get out of the inner city, and he's picked up by a crook who happens to be a relative.'' When clients are vacating a house, Equity Solutions will help sell their appliances and any other belongings they might want to liquidate. Recently, Prescott's sisterin- law began posting Craton's antiques for sale on eBay. ''We try to get them a little money to start a new life,'' Prescott said.
 At times it can be hard to tell where Prescott's do-gooder instincts leave off and self-interest kicks in. Prescott has told me that if clients ask, he will try to work out a forbearance with the bank -- which is to say, some sort of repayment plan that lets them keep their house. ''I'll do that for nothing,'' he said. ''It's good karma.'' No doubt. On the other hand, the majority of homeowners who win forbearances end up back in foreclosure within a year. When they do, they're likely to call Equity Solutions.
 When I dropped in on Prescott in late June, he seemed reflective. He'd spent weeks working on a deal for a house owned by the telemarketer with the dodgy uncle. Prescott had finally reached an understanding with the lender and even had a buyer lined up. But at the last minute, the lender informed him that there were actually two mortgages on the house and that the second had been sold to another bank. Prescott would have to open up an entirely separate negotiation to complete the sale. He stared straight ahead and slowly shook his head as he told me this.
 Still, the recent news on the deal front hadn't been all bad. Shenecial Bailey stopped the auction of her home with a successful bankruptcy filing. In June, her lender allowed the sale of the property to Prescott for $80,000. Bailey promptly went to court and retracted the bankruptcy, a move known as a voluntary dismissal, which preserved her good credit. After the sale -- and a thorough cleaning by Bailey -- Equity Solutions resold the house for $100,000 to an investor the partners had dealt with frequently. Prescott and his partners cleared $11,000. ''It was a small one for us,'' he said. Had the housing market been better, he added, ''we would have made 20.''

HEADLINE: Near Ground Zero, Baby Carriages and Busy Shops

BYLINE: By PATRICK McGEEHAN

 BODY:
Six years ago, in the aftershock of the terrorist attack that reduced the World Trade Center to a smoldering pile, local officials wondered whether people would want to live or work around the financial district again.
 Today, as new residents fill converted office buildings and jam the raucous block party that erupts nightly on Stone Street, the more likely curiosity about Lower Manhattan is: Where did all these people come from, and how can they afford to live here?
 Despite the slow pace of reconstruction at ground zero, the area below Chambers Street is humming with activity, much of it designed to appeal to the well-heeled professionals who are transforming the neighborhood. Already, it has added hundreds of condominium units and hotel rooms, a thriving restaurant row, a private school charging $27,000 a year, a free wireless Internet service, a BMW dealership and an Hermes boutique.
 A Tiffany & Company jewelry store is coming soon, and plans are in place for the arrival of grocery stores, the type of business that the area has long lacked. 
 ''There were very few who would have predicted that Lower Manhattan would have rebounded as quickly as it has, despite all of the false starts and delays and emotional overlays,'' said Carl Weisbrod, president of Trinity Real Estate and former president of the Alliance for Downtown New York. ''There were few people who were quite that optimistic.''
 The rebound is a testament to the healing power of billions of dollars in government aid, like the federal Liberty Bond program, which provided more than $6 billion in tax-exempt financing for reconstruction downtown, as well as various rent and wage subsidies from redevelopment agencies.
 Optimism abounds now among developers and merchants, who are pouring hundreds of millions of dollars into real estate along the narrow streets of Lower Manhattan. They are counting on the district, in its next incarnation, to be not just a collection of office towers and trading floors, but also a self-sustaining residential neighborhood that will appeal to families.
 Even accounting for the exodus of residents immediately after 9/11, the population of Lower Manhattan has increased by more than 10,000 in the last six years, according to census data. To accommodate new residents, more than 6,000 apartments have been created in the last four years, through conversions or construction, and an additional 5,000 are planned, according to the Downtown Alliance. 
 Office space, now in short supply, is renting for more than it did before 9/11. Over the next several years, around 14 million square feet of commercial space is scheduled to be built, replacing the offices and stores destroyed on 9/11, according to data compiled by Cushman & Wakefield, a large real estate brokerage. 
 The economic rebound is indisputable, but it has left some downtown merchants with mixed feelings.
 Karena Nigale has found the new financial district to be more attractive as a place to run a business, but less affordable as a place to live. Since 9/11, she has opened two hair salons -- each called KK Salon -- within a few blocks of the New York Stock Exchange. 
 Ms. Nigale started out catering to investment bankers and traders with $25 shaves and $40 haircuts. But she has expanded to serve a broader clientele, staying open on Saturdays to serve residents of the area.
 ''Before, this neighborhood was operating from 8 in the morning until 5 o'clock in the afternoon,'' and on weekdays only, Ms. Nigale said. She expected her business would soon become a seven-day-a-week operation.
 Ms. Nigale lived above her first salon until the din from the carousers on Stone Street below her windows, along with a rent increase of more than 30 percent, drove her out. Unable to afford a suitable apartment in the sizzling downtown market, Ms. Nigale and her 11-year-old daughter decamped to the Jersey City riverfront about a year ago. 
 ''I need two bedrooms, and there's nothing for less than $4,000 a month around here,'' Ms. Nigale said, speaking from the larger salon she opened on Maiden Lane last year. A place to park would cost at least an additional $400 a month, she said.
 Her business, though, is thriving. Her young customers all have ''big watches, expensive handbags,'' and no qualms about the cost of her services, she said.
 Indeed, the Downtown Alliance, the neighborhood's business improvement district, estimates that the median annual income among the households in the financial district is $165,000, which is about triple the figure for Manhattan as a whole. 
 While salons and grocers may be welcome in the neighborhood, economic development officials argue that maintaining downtown's position as a global corporate center is important for the city and even the nation.
 Nearly 20 million square feet of office space has been lost since 9/11, from the destruction of the World Trade Center, the damage to the Deutsche Bank building and the conversion of older office buildings to residential use. Still, said William Bernstein, the acting president of the Downtown Alliance, ''The financial industries will always be the backbone of Lower Manhattan's economy.''
 A recent sign that downtown's traditional role remains viable is the decision this summer by JPMorgan Chase & Company to build a headquarters for its investment bank on the site of the ruined Deutsche Bank building. The Chase building will stand just a few blocks from where Goldman Sachs is building a 2.1-million-square-foot tower. Both are within a block of ground zero. 
 And 7 World Trade Center, which contains 1.7 million square feet of space, is open and more than half leased. The other buildings planned at ground zero would add 12 million square feet of office space in coming years.
 Office rents downtown are 10 percent higher, at $45 a square foot, than six years ago, and the vacancy rate has dropped below 7 percent, according to data from Cushman & Wakefield. 
 Business owners are finding other uses for some older office buildings besides turning them into condos. Across Broad Street from the stock exchange, a former Bank of America building has been transformed into the Claremont Preparatory School.
 Starting its third year, the school has several hundred students from prekindergarten through eighth grade, said Michael C. Koffler, the chief executive of MetSchools, the operator of Claremont Prep. 
 About 40 percent of them live downtown, and he expects that number to grow as more apartments become available and the neighborhood gains more stores like a Gristede's supermarket planned on Maiden Lane and a Whole Foods proposed for nearby TriBeCa.
 ''You see children in baby carriages all the time,'' Mr. Koffler said. ''You see people walking dogs. There will be many more apartments with three bedrooms, meaning the development community is acknowledging that this will be a community of families.''
 For some, the neighborhood's growing pains have been a frustrating disruption. 
 Tazz Latifi's pet supply shop, Petropolis, sits three blocks south of ground zero in the street-level space of an older apartment building. Since she opened in March 2006, her business has had to weather the relentless reconstruction of the surrounding blocks, Ms. Latifi said.
 Her first unpleasant surprise came last year, when the building was emptied for a conversion to luxury condominiums. Since then, she said, Con Edison has dug up the street outside her shop three times. In recent weeks, some of the local streets have been closed because of last month's fire at the Deutsche Bank building, in which two firefighters died.
 ''It's frustrating for the residents here,'' said Ms. Latifi, 38. ''I have so many customers that have moved because of the noise and the air quality.''
 Peter Poulakakos has had a front-row view of the less tangible changes through the windows of Ulysses' pub on Stone Street and the six other food-service businesses he and his partners operate nearby. Talking over a standing-room-only crowd on a Thursday night in late summer, Mr. Poulakakos recalled that the street, which was first paved in the mid-17th century, was a trash-filled alley a decade ago.
 Now, closed to traffic and lined with restaurants and bars, it is the stage for one of the liveliest social scenes in Manhattan, a slice of South Beach tucked into the financial district -- minus the palm trees and bikinis.
 Inside Ulysses', which stays open until 4 a.m., couples were dancing to salsa music blaring from a D.J.'s booth. Next door at Adrienne's Pizza Bar, which serves until midnight and was named after Mr. Poulakakos's mother, a pair of women were buying a $12 four-cheese pie to take home.
 A belief in the downtown economy's ability to recover from disasters, financial and otherwise, runs in the Poulakakos family. Mr. Poulakakos's father, Harry, ran the Wall Street mainstay Harry's at Hanover Square for decades. He closed it in 2003 after his wife died, but his son and a partner revived it as Harry's Cafe and Steak. 
 In April, Peter Poulakakos took a bigger leap, opening Gold Street, a restaurant that never closes, at the base of 2 Gold Street, a 51-story building where two-bedroom apartments rent for as much as $5,900 a month. 
 ''Downtown still has a ways to go, as far as progress,'' Mr. Poulakakos said. But the tide of sentiment about its prospects has clearly turned, he added.
 ''We get a lot of customers who used to live down here,'' Mr. Poulakakos said. ''They say, 'I wish I was living here now, because it's so different.' ''

HEADLINE: Energy Proposals Go From Tame to Exotic

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
LONG ISLANDERS made it through this summer without a major blackout, although to stay cool they paid steep electric bills in this era of record prices for the oil and gas that fuel utility generators.
 But the challenge of keeping the Island's lights on and its air-conditioners humming in the years to come has energy experts scrambling to satisfy this power-thirsty land of homes filled with big-screen televisions, computers and video games.
 Huge energy projects -- some strikingly innovative -- are competing for approval and billions of dollars, even as a couple of high-profile projects have been scuttled. Complicating the debate over the Island's energy future are transformations in the two entities responsible for the system, the Long Island Power Authority and KeySpan Energy.
 After the change of governors in Albany in January, new leaders are set to take the helm of the authority, which has overseen the electric system since Long Island Lighting Company's demise in 1998. At the same time, the British energy conglomerate National Grid has bought out KeySpan, which inherited Lilco's power plants and the workforce that operates the electric system. 
 Exotic-sounding projects are being explored by various companies and scrutinized by regulators. 
 Atlantic Sea Island has proposed a 60-acre artificial island for a liquefied natural gas terminal south of Long Beach. Broadwater Energy wants a floating liquefied natural gas terminal as big as the Queen Mary anchored in the middle of Long Island Sound. Other companies are considering underwater turbines on the East End to harness tidal currents.
 More conventional proposals include the revamping of the Island's five major power plants, though that would cost billions of dollars. And there are renewed calls to curb consumption, notably from LIPA's new chairman, Kevin S. Law.
 Recent setbacks for a wind-turbine project and an underwater natural gas pipeline in the Sound underscore the inherent risks of such proposals. Mr. Law recommended shelving the authority's plan to erect 40 giant wind turbines off Jones Beach because the cost had soared to $811 million -- quadruple initial estimates. And a federal judge blocked the proposed Islander East pipeline from Connecticut.
 Some other projects are moving forward. The $600 million, 65-mile Neptune cable project now connects to New Jersey for cheaper electricity, some of it coal- and nuclear-generated. An antiquated cable across the Sound will be replaced next year. And the 350-megawatt Caithness Energy power plant is being built in Yaphank. National Grid and the new LIPA leadership are already having an impact.
 National Grid agreed to $236 million in estimated savings to LIPA and promised to clean up about 20 toxic sites inherited from Lilco, though critics of the deal wanted more concessions. The company now owns the five aging power plants and employs the 2,700 workers. 
 The authority, meanwhile, has changed hands from the Republican Pataki administration to the Democratic Spitzer administration. Its longtime chairman and current president, Richard M. Kessel, is leaving. Mr. Law will succeed him, and Gov. Eliot Spitzer will name a new chairman. Serving 2.8 million people, the authority ranks as one of the nation's largest municipal utilities. 
 ''Everything is on the table,'' Mr. Law said in an interview outlining his vision. ''LIPA has been in its infancy, and now we're going into the teenager years. I want to explore what it will be when it grows up. We want to make it a leader in the nation.''
 Mr. Law listed his priorities as conservation, renewable energy, modernizing plants, overseeing National Grid and making the authority more transparent.
 Though Mr. Law effectively ended the wind turbine project, he said he remained committed to renewable energy, including other wind turbine projects. ''No one wants to be held hostage to Mideast oil,'' he said. 
 Mr. Kessel also remains a proponent of wind turbines, calling them the only way to meet state standards for renewable energy.
 Skeptics contend that the wind is not strong enough here. ''Long Island is not a great place for wind power,'' said Matthew C. Cordaro, a former Lilco official who is now an energy professor at the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University.
 One hurdle for renewable energy is that wind, solar and tidal power cost more than fossil fuel, critics say. The public likes the concept, Mr. Law said, ''but if you ask would you pay more for it, then the question gets dicier.''
 Environmentalists dispute the cost comparisons. ''You have to get away from today's cost and look at tomorrow's -- the cost of oil 20 years from now,'' said Adrienne Esposito, executive director of the nonprofit Citizens Campaign for the Environment. 
 There are also hidden costs of fossil fuel, including health hazards, global warming and geopolitical strain, Ms. Esposito said. 
 Some of the renewable-energy technology is experimental, like the tidal turbines recently installed in the East River -- then shut down for modification after a string of mishaps.
 Only about 1,000 homes on Long Island have gone solar, said Gordian Raacke, executive director of the nonprofit Renewable Energy Long Island. Vouching for the savings, he said he pays about $6 a month for electricity after he built an efficient home and installed solar panels.
 As for conservation, Mr. Law said: ''The cheapest way to save money is the plant we don't have to build. We are going to have really aggressive conservation: 15 by 15 -- reducing demand 15 percent by 2015.'' 
 Dr. Cordaro agreed: ''Conservation is the low-hanging fruit, things like replacing all your light bulbs. It makes a lot of sense.''
 Replacing the generators at existing plants would yield more electricity at a lower cost with fewer emissions, energy experts agree. The problem, Mr. Kessel said, is construction and equipment costs that could exceed $1 billion per plant.
 The current power system supplanted Lilco, unpopular for its sketchy service record and electric rates that were the highest in the continental United States. 
 ''We've come a long way from the old Lilco days,'' Mr. Kessel said, ''from the worst performing utility in the state to the best.'' The authority has added 2,000 megawatts; its one-day record for peak demand is about 5,800 megawatts. 
 But customers still grouse about high bills, since the initial savings of about 20 percent after LIPA took over from Lilco have been offset by rising oil and gas prices. The authority also passes along to customers $325 million a year in property taxes. 
 Despite the progress here, critics like Dr. Cordaro say LIPA succumbed to political interference by Republicans. Martin R. Cantor, an economist at Dowling College, lamented that the agency was still saddled with the multibillion-dollar debt from the never-opened Shoreham nuclear plant.
 One former authority board member, Sheldon R. Sackstein, said that it ''could have done much more'' by bidding the deals with KeySpan and National Grid more competitively -- or, better yet, taking over the power plants and workforce as a full-fledged public utility.
 Mr. Kessel said he was dubious about tinkering with the current structure. But his successor, Mr. Law, left the possibility open. ''Maybe it makes sense for those people to be in LIPA,'' he said of KeySpan's workers, ''and for LIPA to own the generation plants.''
