HEADLINE: A Hunt for Big Game Yields a Trophy by G.M.

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER JENSEN

 BODY:
ERROL, N.H.
 WE are hunting moose in northern New Hampshire, a predatory band of three adults and two children in the new Buick Enclave.
 Nicely equipped in all other respects, our 2008 Enclave lacks a gun rack, but that is not a problem on this hunt. While this state does allow moose hunting -- a pursuit that strikes me as presenting all the challenge and peril of bagging a dairy cow -- we are just hoping for a moose sighting to amuse a pair of visiting nephews from the suburbs of Cleveland.
 The newest member of the Buick family, the Enclave went on sale in the spring, in part to fill the void created by the dismissal of the Rainier, Terraza and Rendezvous models, Buick's entries in the S.U.V., minivan and crossover market segments. Expecting one vehicle to replace three might seem like a daunting assignment, but the Enclave is intended to attract buyers who spend more and are import-minded. In any case, the combined sales of the three pink-slipped Buicks amounted to only about 71,000 last year. 
 The name Enclave suggests upper-class luxury, peace and quiet. Frankly, I prefer the name suggested by a colleague -- the 2008 Buick Gated Community -- because that seems even more protective and exclusive. Whatever you call it, the Enclave is quite good, though not perfect. But it certainly provides quiet and soothing family transportation and is a pleasing alternative to a trucklike S.U.V.
 The Enclave shares its car-type mechanical underpinnings, including a six-speed automatic transmission and 3.6-liter V-6 engine, with two cousins in the General Motors family, the GMC Acadia and the Saturn Outlook. The Enclave has three rows of seats, is available in seven- or eight-passenger configurations, and is aimed at competitors like the Acura MDX and Lexus RX 350.
 Prices begin at $32,790 for a front-wheel drive CX; the fancier CXL starts at $34,990. All-wheel drive adds $2,000. 
 The Buick is the most expensive of G.M.'s crossover triplets, although the amount of standard equipment varies among the three. The Acadia starts at $29,845 and the Outlook at $28,340. The fanciest Outlook, with all-wheel drive, is $150 less than the least-expensive front-drive Enclave. The front-drive Enclave CX I tested had options that included a Bose stereo and a DVD player ($1,980); the total on the window sticker was $36,260.
 As dusk enveloped our hunting party, we cruised through Errol here in the northeast corner of the state, an area with a reputation as a moose-rich environment. Some 30 miles of roaming had not resulted in a single moose sighting, but we traveled in comfort. The Enclave's suspension provides a splendid buffer against rough two-lane roads and the cabin is quiet.
 The Enclave gets more soundproofing than its cousins. This reflects G.M.'s idea that a quiet interior should be a virtue of all Buicks; noise isolation has become a main selling point for Lexus, a brand Buick hopes to compete against. 
 We also had a pleasing amount of room. During our week in the Enclave we routinely carried five adults and two children on hourlong drives without anyone being uncomfortable, even when two adults shared the third row with a child. There was enough room behind the third row (19 cubic feet) to carry duffel bags and a small cooler.
 The cabin's design showed that G.M. was successful in its effort to upgrade its interiors, apparently after concluding that this is where people sit and it should look nice. But there were some minor problems.
 Rear visibility wasn't good because of the huge roof pillars in the back. A ''smart slide'' feature for moving the second-row captain's chairs forward (to allow easier entry to the third row) was balky. A strap used to release the seatback and allow it to fold forward proved a real hazard; pulling it sent the seatback slamming forward at great speed, whacking anybody in its path. 
 The good news for families is that all Enclaves have curtain air bags to provide head protection in a side-impact crash for all three rows and skid-correcting electronic stability control.
 There is also OnStar, which now offers turn-by-turn route guidance, a feature I found easier to use than many traditional navigation systems. Call OnStar and give the operator an address, and audible and written instructions are sent to the vehicle. The system worked well even in Boston, one of America's great navigational challenges.
 Toting all this around is an independent suspension that is quite a trickster. During my first miles around town it seemed as if the steering was a little too light and the suspension too soft. It was easy to conclude that the Enclave was sloppy. But my attitude changed as I drove New Hampshire's zigzag two-lanes, steadily increasing speed as I gained confidence in the Buick's handling. Yes, the body leans a little, but the Enclave corners quite well for such a big vehicle.
 G.M.'s engineers get no points for being weight-watchers. With all-wheel drive, the Enclave weighs about 5,000 pounds, a considerable load for an engine rated at 275 horsepower and 251 pound-feet of torque. The six-speed automatic was developed with Ford, which uses it on vehicles including the Edge and the 2008 Taurus. 
 With seven people on board, the powertrain did an adequate job, though at times the transmission was slow to downshift, leaving the driver waiting for acceleration. Ford seems to have done a better job of programming the transmission for its vehicles.
 For the front-drive model I tested, the Environmental Protection Agency estimates fuel economy at 16 miles a gallon in the city and 24 on the highway. Those figures were calculated under the new 2008 formula, which is intended to be more realistic than previous estimates.
 The Enclave has four-wheel disc brakes. Initially, the brake pedal seems firm and reassuring. But it loses some resistance about midway, slightly undermining confidence.
 A dozen or so miles north of Errol, as dusk fades to darkness, we admit to failure in our moose hunt and decide to head home. A small dirt road looks like the perfect turnaround spot, and I pull in. 
 There, maybe 100 feet away, chomping on some greenery, is a moose. The moose looks up and continues its buffet, assuming we have come in peace. See what I mean about the challenge of shooting a moose?
 Clearly the moose is not impressed with us or the Enclave. I, on the other hand, have grown to like it, and it has been so long since I liked a Buick that the experience is slightly disorienting. This big wagon offers families comfort, competent handling and a solid package of safety features. 
 Our hunt successful, the nephews wonder whether they may turn on the DVD player, and if there is a shortcut home. No, the house is a couple of hours away, but in the Enclave that's not a bad thing. 
 INSIDE TRACK: Wow. This is a Buick?

To the Editor:

 I am getting very tired of hearing how the Fed can raise or lower interest rates in order to solve our economic woes. 
 A lot of us have just plain dropped out of the bottom of this economy. My hourly salary is equivalent to 1 1/2 gallons of whole milk as sold at the store where I work.

HEADLINE: What's New In the Old Country?

BYLINE: By MARK BLANKENSHIP

 BODY:
THE Troubles are over, but the trouble has just begun. 
 That could be the tag line for ''Rock Doves,'' a savage drama by the Northern Irish playwright Marie Jones that receives its world premiere Sunday at the Irish Arts Center in Midtown Manhattan. Set in present-day Belfast, it depicts four outsiders -- including a transvestite and a homeless man -- enduring the aftermath of the Belfast Agreement, which ostensibly ended paramilitary violence in Northern Ireland in 1998. Of course declaring peace isn't the same as having it, and as she's hiding from the hostility in her neighborhood, a prostitute named Bella declares, ''Compared to what's going on out there, we're normal.''
 Its thorny view of peacetime makes ''Rock Doves''' an obvious fit for the arts center, which was founded in 1972 to demonstrate the breadth of Irish life and culture through classes, film, music, dance, the visual arts -- and theater. 
 The center's leaders say they especially want their programming to reflect watershed recent events -- like the nation's economic boom and the restoration of Northern Ireland's government -- that are pushing Ireland into a new age. 
 Pauline Turley, vice chairwoman of the center's board, said such developments weren't always reflected in the cultural works that appear in New York. ''For a lot of people their exposure to Irish culture in the mainstream is the drunken Irish priest or some other stereotype,'' she said. ''To have a place that celebrates so much more about being Irish is important. Our challenge is to see Irishness in all its complexities.''
 That's partly why the center staged ''The Blowin of Baile Gall'' in 2005. Featuring an African character who joins a local construction team, Ronan Noone's drama explores the tension created by an influx of immigrants to Western Ireland, a subject little discussed in the United States. 
 In a telephone interview, the actor Gabriel Byrne, who has advocated on the center's behalf with the Irish government, said that such performances can be much more than entertainment. ''The danger of Irish culture becoming stuck in the notions of the 19th century is very real,'' he said. ''Irish-American culture is in danger of dying if it doesn't get the chance to reflect the new Ireland.''
 Mr. Byrne added that a ''new self-confidence'' created by Ireland's recent prosperity -- a report from the Bank of Ireland cited a 19 percent increase in the nation's net wealth in 2006 over the previous year -- has pushed the Irish to reinvigorate their cultural representation abroad.
 In its current state, though, the Irish Arts Center can hardly support such ambition. Tucked away on West 51st Street near 11th Avenue, a block in the Clinton neighborhood where boarded-up windows abound, its 99-seat theater and unassuming classrooms hardly match the grandeur of, say, Scandinavia House on Park Avenue. ''We want to succeed,'' Ms. Turley said, ''but we're almost afraid to be too successful, because we simply don't have the capacity.''
 International efforts are under way to build a new home. Mr. Byrne, who said he wants the center to include meeting and social space, said he would meet with Prime Minister Bertie Ahern of Ireland this month to discuss expansion plans. 
 Christine Quinn, the New York City Council speaker and Irish-American herself, has also championed growth. ''For the Irish Arts Center to become a permanent part of the cultural infrastructure,'' she said, ''we need to make sure it has a physical space that reflects the contribution that Irish people have made and continue to make to New York.''
 As for the center's programming, the city has committed to increasing its support to $40,000 next year from $6,000 this year. Aidan Connolly, the center's executive director, also said that the Irish government, which provided about 4 percent of the center's $693,000 budget this year, had urged him ''to apply for greater levels of funding for programming.'' 
 Still, the money must develop projects people want to see. A study by the center suggests that its patrons crave old-fashioned fare as much as political art. ''There's clearly a population of our supporters and audiences who are very interested in things like traditional Irish music,'' Mr. Connolly said, adding that classes on step dancing and the Irish language are among the center's most popular.
 Besides, strong work about the current Irish moment may not always be easy to find. Ciaran O'Reilly, producing director of the Irish Repertory Theater, one of New York's most respected nonprofit theater companies, said he also wants to stage the ''voice of the new Ireland,'' though he hasn't found the ideal play to reflect it. ''Maybe it takes time to gain that perspective,'' he said.
 ''People like to think the place they came from will always be there, but in a way -- and it's a sad thing -- the bigger cities are becoming more homogenized,'' Mr. O'Reilly added. ''If people don't remember their heritage, it gets lost, and I think the theater's job is to heighten our sense both of what is and what was.''
 Mr. Connolly said the center's traditional programming could help awaken New Yorkers to the culture's future. ''Whatever it is that's hooking people into Irish arts, that's great,'' he explained. ''As long as they're interested, we can take that opportunity to stretch their consciousness and take them in a new direction.''

LENGTH: 1408 words

HEADLINE: Nonfiction Chronicle

BYLINE: Reviews by MICK SUSSMAN. 
Mick Sussman produces the home page for The New York Times on the Web.

 BODY:
DOMINION OF MEMORIES: Jefferson, Madison, and the Decline of Virginia. By Susan Dunn. (Basic Books, $27.50.) Virginia's ''brilliant, forward-looking, transforming leaders,'' Dunn writes, ''created a nation'' and then controlled the executive branch for 32 of the first 36 years of America's constitutional government. Virginia was once the wealthiest and most populous state, but by the early decades of the 19th century, its soil had been depleted by primitive farming methods; its schools were ''miserable,'' according to Jefferson; and its roads were ''execrable,'' a disgruntled visitor said. Its constitution preserved elitist government long after most states had expanded suffrage, and its plantation aristocracy deliberately hindered the economic dynamism that was modernizing the North. 
Slavery's role in the decline of the South is an old story, but Dunn, a professor of humanities at Williams College, finds fresh insights by making a case study of Virginia. She emphasizes the significance of lesser-known figures like Thomas Roderick Dew, who in 1832 published an essay that laid the intellectual groundwork for an uncompromisingly pro-slavery ideology, and Nathaniel Beverley Tucker, who anticipated secession with an 1836 novel envisioning a Southern rebellion. Dunn's chief aim, though, is to show the complicity of Jefferson and Madison in Virginia's stagnation. Both men strained against plantation dogma, Jefferson because of his egalitarian creed and Madison because of a wavering faith in the national government he'd helped design. Yet they both acquiesced as states' rights radicals adduced anti-Federalist pronouncements by the two founders to trump moderate opponents. ''The seeds of Virginia's decline had been adroitly planted in fertile soil by the great patriarchs themselves,'' Dunn concludes. 
 1001 NIGHTS IN IRAQ: The Shocking Story of an American Forced to Fight for Saddam Against the Country He Loves. By Shant Kenderian. (Atria, paper, $15.) An Iraqi of Armenian descent who moved to Chicago with his mother after his parents separated, Kenderian describes himself as ''a guy with really bad timing.'' He certainly picked an inauspicious moment to visit his father in Iraq: September 1980, seven days before Saddam Hussein attacked Iran. Trapped behind closed borders, Kenderian evaded military service by attending college. But after graduating in 1985, he chose enlistment over execution and began a three-year stint in the Iraqi Navy. His luck was no better in the sequel. After the Iran war, Kenderian's green card was in the middle of being processed when Hussein invaded Kuwait in 1990. The bulk of ''1001 Nights in Iraq,'' describing his life as a soldier during the Persian Gulf war, is the stuff of a standard battle memoir: comradeship, bad food, sleepless nights and boredom interrupted by violence. But this account is distinguished by Kenderian's wry humor and peculiar predicament. With his deep faith in Christianity and America, he was even more reluctant than most of Hussein's conscripts. Facing a hopeless fight against an American warplane, Kenderian's unit surrendered. As a P.O.W., he charmed his guards with his distinctively American ingenuousness; he even fell in love. Kenderian was eventually allowed to return to America, where his fortunes improved strikingly. He became an engineer, a father and a citizen. And he caught another break when he was broadcast reading from this book, which was originally self-published, on ''This American Life.'' 
 TORTURE: When the Unthinkable Is Morally Permissible. By Mirko Bagaric and Julie Clarke. (State University of New York, cloth, $53.50; paper, $17.95.) This book will convince you either that utilitarian principles justify torture in certain circumstances or that scholars in thrall to a hypothesis can rationalize almost anything. Bagaric and Clarke, who teach law at Deakin University in Australia, offer a forthright defense of a practice whose proponents often resort to euphemism. The authors draw a distinction between ''consequential moral theories,'' which judge an act based on its outcome, and ''nonconsequential'' theories, which judge an act intrinsically and are the basis for the concept of universal human rights. Bagaric and Clarke reject this latter view, declaring that ''absolute right'' theories ''lack a coherent foundation.'' These approaches are not always in opposition, they note, since human rights can function as ''shortcuts'' in performing a ''utilitarian calculus.'' To evaluate when the ends justify the means of torture, Bagaric and Clarke have devised a quasi-mathematical formula involving factors like ''the number of lives at risk'' and ''the immediacy of the harm.'' But how reliable is their ethical calculator? Rather than trusting individuals to determine when torture would maximize happiness, many enlightened societies have opted for a blanket prohibition. Such moral absolutes have a utilitarian purpose: they act as restraints against shortsighted arguments for sanctioning barbarity in the name of expediency.
 THE SHORT BUS: A Journey Beyond Normal. By Jonathan Mooney. (Holt, $25.) After being classified as learning-disabled in third grade, Mooney rode the ''short bus'' with other special-ed students, a stigma so mortifying he later contemplated suicide. But he persevered, graduating from Brown University and writing a book with David Cole called ''Learning Outside the Lines.'' In his latest book, Mooney travels coast to coast in a dilapidated short bus to interview people ''who had once been labeled 'abnormal' or 'disabled.' '' These portraits are endearing. He meets an eccentric, possibly autistic man who has befriended a group of mathematicians; a blind and deaf girl who curses in sign language; and a former fisherman who is considering gender reassignment. Mooney makes some discordant attempts at philosophizing in this chatty narrative (his epigraph is from Foucault: ''The judges of normality are present everywhere''). And although he thinks the ''medical model'' of treating developmental disabilities is dehumanizing, he is vague about the ''community care'' approach he favors. Mooney, who suggests that reading remediation is a waste of time in some cases, suffered as a child not just because he was ostracized but also because he simply wanted to read and couldn't. It's not necessarily more compassionate to tolerate disabilities than to try to correct them. But it feels like bullying to pick on this book's limitations. Mooney's target audience is not policy makers but his fellow misfits, and his boundless empathy will surely console those who also face the worst that cruel schoolchildren and the educational bureaucracy have to offer.
 REVENGE OF THE DONUT BOYS: True Stories of Lust, Fame, Survival and Multiple Personality. By Mike Sager. (Thunder's Mouth, paper, $16.95.) Like his journalistic precursors Tom Wolfe and Hunter S. Thompson, Sager writes frenetic, off-kilter pop-sociological profiles of Americans in all their vulgarity and vitality. But compared with the new journalists, who celebrated the subjectivity of the narrator, Sager is a relatively self-effacing observer. He writes with flair, but only in the service of an omnivorous curiosity. In the articles collected here -- published between 1985 and 2006, mostly in Esquire magazine, where Sager is a writer at large -- the famous, almost famous and not famous all get the same Sager treatment. He is teasingly affectionate (Tom Araya of the heavy-metal band Slayer speaks like ''a mixture of Valley doper, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle and mambo king'') and meticulous (he's the kind of reporter who notes his subject's shoe size). He defies expectations in pieces that lesser writers would play for satire or sensationalism: Newark teenagers who steal cars for fun, a group of professional beach volleyball players who go on strike, a Frederick's of Hollywood model who wants to lock in a husband while she's still young. Sager's celebrity interviews -- Roseanne Barr describing her multiple personality disorder, Ice Cube pondering race and fame -- are sympathetic but not fawning. The book's closing selection, in which Sager talks to other people named Mike Sager (a police captain, a meteorologist, a politician), is not, as it might seem, narcissistic. His conclusion ought to be read instead as a Whitmanesque ode to teeming humanity's mystical unity: ''Call us all Mike Sager.''

HEADLINE: Mileage Ratings Are Still Estimates, Though Closer to Reality

BYLINE: By CHERYL JENSEN

 BODY:
SOME Americans are skeptical of almost anything the government says. But even the most cynical citizens find it hard to dispute a much-repeated statement from one federal agency: Your actual mileage may vary. 
 The disconnect between the Environmental Protection Agency's fuel-economy numbers on new-vehicle window stickers, where that cautionary note is printed, and the mileage that owners actually record is well known. In part, the disparity is a result of federal testing standards that no longer represent traffic conditions in the United States. 
 But starting with the 2008 models, shoppers can have more faith in the window stickers that they study in dealership showrooms; for the first time since 1984, the E.P.A. is revising its method for calculating fuel economy to better reflect realities of the road.
 Comparing vehicles that are unchanged from their 2007 specification, consumers will see lower miles-per-gallon estimates on the 2008 versions. The E.P.A. says city mileage estimates for most vehicles will drop about 12 percent, on average, and highway estimates about 8 percent, for 2008 models that are mechanically unchanged from their 2007 counterparts. Mileage estimates for hybrid vehicles will drop as much as 30 percent. 
 Cheer up -- this doesn't mean that a 100-mile trip will cost more, only that the agency is admitting that the estimates have been optimistic.
 ''The old labels were broken,'' said David Friedman, research director for the vehicles program at the Union of Concerned Scientists, an environmental advocacy group. 
 ''The driving cycles just don't represent the way people actually drive,'' he said, referring to the speeds and road conditions simulated in the test. ''The hardest acceleration in the driving cycles they were using was the equivalent of going from zero to 60 in 18 seconds. 
 ''What the E.P.A. is doing is definitely a step in the right direction,'' Mr. Friedman said.
 The agency adopted the new calculations last December, but automakers were given until Sept. 1 of this year to comply. Because 2007 models with the old window stickers and mileage ratings will be sold for a while alongside 2008 models with the new stickers and ratings, some confusion is inevitable. 
 The gap between government estimates and actual mileage is no small matter for consumers, especially when gas prices are high. The AAA, formerly the American Automobile Association, released a 2006 study in which 36 out of 41 vehicles it looked at fell short of the E.P.A. estimate by an average of 4 miles a gallon, or almost 16 percent. 
 David Champion, the auto testing director for Consumer Reports, said that when the E.P.A. figures don't match up to real-world driving, the owners may be spending hundreds of dollars more in operating costs each year than they were led to believe. 
 In its October 2005 issue, Consumer Reports published an analysis that showed fuel economy could be half as much as the fuel economy rating, based on comparing the E.P.A. ratings with the mileage that Consumers Reports testers measured for 303 cars and trucks over the 2000 to 2006 model years.
 ''We think that the new mileage is much closer to reality, much closer to our numbers than in the past,'' Mr. Champion said. 
 When the E.P.A. revised rating methods in 1984, it lowered the city fuel economy figure by 10 percent and the highway fuel economy by 22 percent. In addition to other changes, the E.P.A. has adjusted the city and highway tests downward again.
 Mr. Friedman of the scientists' group describes the new formula the E.P.A is using as ''smarter markdowns.'' The 2008 numbers, which take into account results from three tests already used in certifying emissions compliance, involve higher speeds, air-conditioning use and colder outdoor temperatures. 
 While the current highway test has a top speed of 60 m.p.h. and an average speed of only 48, the emissions driving cycle calls for a maximum speed of 80 m.p.h., an average of 62 -- and more aggressive acceleration. As in the past, automakers test their own cars and provide the data to the environmental agency, though the E.P.A. conducts spot checks at its laboratory in Ann Arbor, Mich.
 There are also differences between what the E.P.A. is doing this year with 2008 models and what automakers will be required to do for 2011 models. At that time, the companies will be required to run vehicles through the three additional emissions tests (in addition to the current city and highway driving cycles) and use the data from specific vehicles to calculate fuel economy. Both the old and new regulations include provisions for averaging results in cases where one engine may be shared among several vehicles.
 For 2008 models, what consumers will see on window stickers -- which are being redesigned to feature fuel-cost information more prominently -- is a far bigger mileage drop for high-mileage vehicles than for S.U.V.'s.
 The biggest hits in terms of miles per gallon are going to be taken by hybrids. But many hybrid owners already know that it is hard to match the window sticker in normal driving.
 In the past, Toyota Prius owners have used online forums to both boast and complain about their mileage. Some have said their mileage was closer to 30 m.p.g. and asked what they were doing wrong, while drivers who claimed to get 50 m.p.g. were offering tips to attain the higher mileage.
 When people see new fuel-economy figures for hybrids that are lower than those published in the past, will they switch to gasoline-only versions of models that are available both ways?
 ''That's the problem we face,'' said John German, manager of environmental and energy analysis for Honda. Mr. German spent 13 years at the E.P.A., where he worked on developing the emission testing cycles that are being used as part of the new formula.
 But, Mr. German says, drivers should compare the Civic Hybrid with a conventional Civic and look at the gallons saved. ''It's not really going to change under the new system,'' he said. ''You are still going to save the same amount of dollars with the new ratings as you did under the old ratings.''
 Toyota says that once the dust settles on the label change, consumers will again see that the Prius is the most fuel-efficient vehicle in its class.
 Despite the redesigned window stickers, some information will not show up there, like the mileage of a flexible-fuel vehicle running on E85. The only mileage figures potential buyers will see is the fuel economy when the vehicle is running on gasoline. Because ethanol contains less energy per gallon than gasoline, an engine must burn more ethanol to go the same distance.
 More changes are coming in 2010 that will apply to 2011 models. For the first time, vehicles with a gross weight rating (vehicle weight plus the maximum cargo capacity) of 8,500 to 10,000 pounds, which includes large S.U.V.'s like the Hummer H2, will have to post mileage figures on the window sticker. 
 But in some ways the closer-to-reality mileage figures will be little more than window dressing. The corporate average fuel economy that automakers must attain will still be based on the old mileage numbers. Under the law, each automaker must maintain minimum fleet averages for its cars and trucks to avoid financial penalties. Likewise, the revised figures will not be used to determine whether a vehicle is subject to a gas-guzzler tax penalty; that assessment will also continue to be based on the old test regime.
 In effect, while the government is admitting that the old method used to estimate fuel economy was unrealistic, it isn't forcing automakers to take action on the shortfall in mileage promises. 
 ''At the end of the day this helps remind everyone how bad our fuel economy is,'' Mr. Friedman said. ''Part of what people need to see is that we are in a lot more trouble than we thought.''

HEADLINE: Navigating a Path Through a Turbulent Housing Market

BYLINE: By TIM GRAY

 BODY:
IF you're considering wading into the housing market as a buyer, seller or borrower, be prepared for choppy water and even an occasional rogue wave. Summer may be just about over, but hurricane season, at least in housing, continues. 
 Home prices are falling. Some lenders are going out of business. Others are phasing out certain loans, including so-called subprime and no-documentation mortgages, making financing tougher to get. And over the last six months, mortgage rates have risen, especially on the big loans that are popular in costly cities like New York and San Francisco. 
 On top of that, the Mortgage Bankers Association announced earlier this month that, in the second quarter of this year, a rising number of borrowers had fallen so far behind in their payments that they were entering foreclosure. The number of people entering foreclosure has been rising since the first quarter of last year, according to the association. 
 All the upheaval has turned lenders cautious, said Christopher J. Mayer, a professor of real estate, finance and economics at Columbia University. ''We're really seeing a real pullback in credit,'' he said. ''If that doesn't reverse itself in the coming weeks and months, we're going to see a sharp decline in the housing market.'' 
 With prices falling, home sellers might have to accept lower prices than they had hoped for, Professor Mayer said. People who had planned to refinance might find themselves with fewer options for a new loan or, in the worst case, none at all, he said. Buyers might find it tougher to qualify for a mortgage. Even people with good credit might find that lenders are demanding more documentation or eyeing their home appraisal more carefully. 
 Until earlier this year, the economy was awash in mortgage money. Home prices had waxed, interest rates had waned and lenders were offering up loans with a beguiling variety of terms and options, making it easier for people to qualify.
 ''Banks were practically giving out loans at the drive-up window,'' said Paul S. Havemann, a vice president at HSH Associates, a Pompton Plains, N.J., company that tracks mortgage rates, terms and trends. Even people with bad or limited credit histories -- so-called subprime borrowers -- were finding banks eager to compete for their business. 
 If you've followed the tumult on Wall Street in recent weeks, you know that the woes of subprime borrowers have rippled through the economy, buffeting banks and hedge funds. A few big lenders, like Countrywide Financial, have landed in financial trouble, and banks like Washington Mutual have laid off staff.
 At the same time, real estate prices have faltered. At the end of June, the latest period for which data is available, 15 of the 20 major metropolitan housing markets tracked by the S&P/Case-Shiller Housing indices were seeing declining prices, compared with a year earlier. 
 Climbing mortgage rates could continue to push down housing prices. Within the last couple of weeks, yields on 10-year Treasury notes, which tend to be a barometer for longer-term mortgage rates, have been falling, said Keith T. Gumbinger, a vice president with HSH Associates. 
 ''The downward draft in Treasuries is exerting downward pressure on mortgage rates, but not as much as normal,'' he said. That's because investors remain uneasy about the mortgage market, he said. 
 Still, despite the upheaval, much of the mortgage market has been relatively stable, Mr. Gumbinger said. About half of the mortgages made in the United States are owned or guaranteed by Fannie Mae and other government-chartered guarantors. These companies buy loans from lenders, securitize them and sell the securities to investors. Guaranteed loans must hew to strict underwriting standards and so far have shown no problems, he said. 
 Many home buyers shouldn't have trouble getting mortgages, though they will pay higher rates than they would have done a few months ago, he said. As of Friday, the average nationwide rate for a 30-year fixed rate mortgage conforming to Fannie Mae standards was 6.37 percent, up from 6.16 percent in March, Mr. Gumbinger said. 
 Rates for 30-year jumbo mortgages -- that is, loans too big to be guaranteed by Fannie Mae and the other guarantors -- had gone higher, reaching 7.26 percent on average, up from 6.36 percent in March, he said. 
 Rising rates hurt anyone who needs a mortgage -- all else being equal, they mean that you must buy a cheaper house -- but they could be especially painful for people who signed up for an adjustable-rate mortgage (ARM) over the last several years and are now hoping to refinance. 
 IF, for example, you took a so-called 3/1 adjustable-rate mortgage in 2004, when their benchmark interest rates dropped to 40-year lows, your monthly payment may soon jump, if it hasn't already, said Greg McBride, senior financial analyst at Bankrate.com. A 3/1 ARM offers an interest rate that is fixed for the first three years and then adjusts annually. 
 ''Somebody who got in at 4.5 percent in 2004 could now be looking at 7.25 or 7.5 percent,'' Mr. McBride said. On a $200,000 loan, that equates to a difference of about $400 a month. If mortgage rates continue to increase, payments could swell next year, too. 
 What are your options if you're worried about rising rates? 
 Risk-tolerant home buyers still might consider an ARM. The initial rates on these loans are often, but not always, lower than those for fixed-rate ones. On Friday the national average rate on a one-year ARM was 6.35 percent, according to HSH Associates, about the same as the rate for a 30-year conforming mortgage. Lenders also offer ARM's with initial fixed-rate periods of one, five, seven and even 10 years. 
 Be aware that borrowing via an ARM means, in essence, betting either that interest rates will be steady or fall once your loan begins to adjust, or that you'll be able to refinance. 
 That risk makes sense for people who are sure they will move before the adjustments begin. ''If you don't need that 30-year protection, there's no point in paying for it,'' said David C. Schneider, president of the home loans group at Washington Mutual in Seattle. ''And you need to understand that you do pay for it.'' Over the life of a loan, a higher interest rate can translate into tens of thousands of dollars in additional payments. 
 As is typically the case in financial matters, it pays to shop around when seeking a mortgage. At the moment, 30-year fixed-rate loans are a better deal than many shorter-term ARM's, Mr. Gumbinger said. The Federal Reserve, in a pamphlet on adjustable-rate loans, cautions that consumers should ''keep in mind that brokers are not required to find the best deal for you unless they have contracted with you to act as your agent.'' 
 Allen Fishbein, director of housing and credit policy at the Consumer Federation of America in Washington, said, ''Borrowers assume that brokers and lenders won't make them a loan that they can't repay. What we found with the subprime meltdown is that that's not the case.''
 Some people may find that they can't refinance, perhaps because they've landed in financial trouble or because the value of their home has fallen. 
 Falling prices can put ARM borrowers in a vise: Not only do they face higher interest rates, but their home's value may not cover the amount of the original loan. To refinance, they typically have to make up the difference. If they can't, she may be stuck. ''Brokers will tell you that you can always refi out of a loan, but you can't always,'' said Rick Harper, vice president and director of housing for the Consumer Credit Counseling Service of San Francisco. ''There's usually somebody willing to make you a deal, but it might not be a better loan.''
 A better option might be to call the company that services your loan and see if it is willing to reduce your payments temporarily, extend the term of your loan or, if it comes to that, even help you sell your house, he said. 
 People often mistakenly assume that lenders are eager to claim the homes of borrowers who fall behind on their payments, said Mr. Schneider of Washington Mutual. In fact, lenders typically lose money on foreclosures because of administrative and legal costs and the loss that they often take on the sale of the house. 
 ''From our perspective, there's nothing good about us taking a home,'' he added. ''It's the worst possible outcome for everybody.''

THE NEWS Americans born in 2005 can expect to live 78 years, the National Center for Health Statistics reported.
 BEHIND THE NEWS Life expectancy has been rising steadily, up from 75.8 years in 1995 and 69.6 years in 1955. One reason: deaths from heart disease, cancer and stroke, the nation's top killers, continue to decline. Whites can expect to live five years longer than blacks; women, five years longer than men. ''We should continue to see improvements'' as leading causes of death decline, said one expert. 
 THE NEWS You may be living longer, but more of you are also working longer, the Census Bureau found in its annual American Community Survey.
 BEHIND THE NEWS By choice or out of necessity, the number of people 65 to 74 who were working or looking for work rose to one in four in 2006 from one in five in 2000. ''People are living longer and they need more resources,'' said Yung-Ping Chen, an economist at the University of Massachusetts, Boston. South Dakota had the highest percentage; West Virginia, the lowest.
 THE NEWS Three out of four workers drove to their jobs by themselves in 2006, according to another finding by the Census Bureau. 
 BEHIND THE NEWS Only about 11 percent shared a ride and just 5 percent took public transportation. Commutes averaged 25 minutes, though New Yorkers spent an average of 31 minutes getting to work while folks in North Dakota made it in 15 minutes. Despite computers, fax machines, personal digital assistants and good old cellphones, just 4 percent worked at home.
 THE NEWS Millions of Americans strained to pay their rent or mortgage last year, despite signs of a slowdown in the housing market.
 BEHIND THE NEWS Half of the nation's renters and about a third of mortgage holders spent at least 30 percent of their gross income on housing, the Census Bureau found, an increase of about 1.5 million households compared with 2005. The data suggests that incomes did not keep up with rising housing prices as lenders let home buyers borrow more relative to their earnings. 
 THE NEWS Hablas espanol? One in five people over age 5 spoke a language other than English at home last year, with Spanish being the most common.
 BEHIND THE NEWS The number is up slightly from what the Census Bureau found in 2000. In some states, the numbers were dramatic. Forty-three percent of California residents spoke another language at home; in Los Angeles, the number was 53 percent. 
 The next five, after California: New Mexico, Texas, New York, Arizona and New Jersey.

HEADLINE: Bless This Mess

BYLINE: By AMANDA HESSER

 BODY:
At dinner recently at Mercat, a new Catalan restaurant in the East Village, my friends and I ordered the salt cod fritters. Like tripe and quenelles, salt cod fritters exist in a culinary sphere reserved for restaurant kitchens. Who at home is going to soak salt cod for a day, mash it up with some other ingredients and deep-fry it -- coating the kitchen with a mist of oil -- for what is essentially a bar snack? Jeffrey Steingarten or Deb at SmittenKitchen.com might bother, but that's their problem.
 The rest of us might opt for soaking salt cod or deep-frying, but not both together. I am here to argue for doing more of the latter. All over the world, people eat fritters. Shrimp fritters, zucchini fritters, banana fritters, corn fritters. When Americans travel, we eat fritters. But then, for reasons I cannot understand, we don't make them back home. 
 It couldn't be that we're still afraid of fried foods: it's well known that if food is fried at a high enough temperature and then properly drained, it can contain no more cooking fat than something that's sauteed (people forget that with sauteed food, you eat the fat). And it couldn't be that the mess argument has won. Kitchens are nothing more than workshops. Have you ever heard a woodworker say he doesn't like to sand because of the dust? (Frying makes a mess, it's true. But many fritters can be fried in advance and either eaten cool, as is the custom of tapas bars in Spain, or reheated in a 200-degree oven, so there's plenty of time to clean up and shower.)
 Perhaps it's because we're a grilling nation, proud of the game of fire and smoke. But I counter this argument with the fact that we're also a snacking nation. And fritters are all about snacking.
 The old idea behind fritters was to stretch an ingredient like zucchini, corn or clams. You either make a batter -- usually with a little egg and baking powder in it for leavening -- and mix in bits of the ingredient you're stretching, or you dip those ingredients into the batter just before frying. I grew up eating what my grandmother called ''critter fritters,'' made the former way with crab and seasoned with Worcestershire sauce, garlic and beer. Critter fritters made the most of leftover bits of crab, with the added benefit of being delicious.
 Today it should be the pleasure of fritters -- crisp, luscious poofs -- rather than their economy that keeps us making them. A few tips to get you on your way: chilling the batter before frying helps hold the batter together as it drops into the oil and makes the fritter cook more evenly. Lots of recipes have you pour three inches of cooking fat into a large deep fryer, which is nothing but a big waste. Use a narrow saucepan and less than two inches of cooking fat. Sure, a few will stick to the bottom, and sure, you'll have to do them in batches, but you'll get over it. And off you'll go, serving fritters.
 Critter Fritters
 1 cup flour
 1 teaspoon kosher salt
 1 1/2 teaspoons baking powder
 1 egg, lightly beaten
 2 tablespoons milk
 1/4 cup beer
 2 1/2 tablespoons lemon juice
 1/2 teaspoon Worcestershire sauce
 1 clove garlic, minced
 2 teaspoons finely chopped parsley
 8 ounces fresh lump crab meat
 Canola oil or shortening, for frying
 Lemon wedges, for serving.
 1. In a bowl, mix together the flour, salt and baking powder. Make a well in the center and add the egg, milk, beer, lemon juice and Worcestershire sauce. Gradually blend the liquid into the flour mixture. Mix the batter just until it is no longer lumpy. Fold in the garlic, parsley and crab meat. Chill for 30 minutes.
 2. In a heavy saucepan, heat 1 to 2 inches of oil over medium-high heat; it's hot enough when it quickly browns a small drop of batter. Drop the batter by the tablespoonful into the oil and fry, turning once, until puffed and golden on both sides, about 3 minutes. Drain on paper towels. Makes 20 fritters. Adapted from the author's grandmother, Helen Getz.
 Basque Chorizo and Cornmeal Fritters
 * cup cornmeal
 1/4 cup flour
 1 tablespoon chopped parsley
 1/2 teaspoon kosher salt
 * cup sparkling water
 1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil
 Canola oil, for frying
 8 ounces chorizo, cut into 1/8 -inch slices or cubes.
 1. In a bowl, combine the cornmeal, flour, parsley, salt, sparkling water and olive oil. Mix until smooth. Heat 1 inch of oil in a heavy saucepan over medium-high heat; it's ready when it quickly browns a small drop of batter.
 2. Dip each piece of chorizo in the batter and lower into the hot oil. Fry until golden on all sides, about 2 minutes. Drain on paper towels. May be served warm or at room temperature. Serves 6 as an appetizer. Adapted from ''La Cocina de Mama'' by Penelope Casas.
 Shrimp Fritters Wrapped in Lettuce and Herbs 
 Chopped raw shrimp are sticky, so no batter is needed -- a little rice flour holds the fritter together.
 10 ounces small shrimp, peeled and chopped
 1/4 cup thinly sliced scallion
 2 teaspoons minced ginger
 1 dried red chili, ground with a mortar and pestle
 1 tablespoon fish sauce
 2 teaspoons toasted sesame oil
 1/2 teaspoon kosher salt
 1/2 teaspoon sugar
 2 teaspoons rice flour
 Canola oil, for frying
 12 cilantro sprigs
 24 mint leaves
 12 bibb lettuce leaves 
 2 limes, quartered.
 1. In a bowl, combine the shrimp, scallion, ginger, chili, fish sauce, sesame oil, salt, sugar and rice flour.
 2. In a heavy saucepan, heat 2 inches of oil over medium-high heat. When the oil is hot, drop the shrimp in flattened golf-ball-size patties into the oil. Fry until golden on all sides, turning once, 1 to 2 minutes. Drain on paper towels. To serve, place a fritter, a cilantro sprig and two mint leaves on a lettuce leaf, sprinkle with lime juice, roll up and eat immediately. Makes about 12 fritters.
 Plum Fritters
 1 cup flour
 1/2 teaspoon kosher salt
 1/2 cup plus 1 tablespoon sugar
 3 eggs, separated
 2 1/2 tablespoons plum brandy (or other eau de vie)
 1 teaspoon cinnamon
 Canola oil or shortening, for frying
 6 small ripe plums, pitted and halved.
 1. In a bowl, mix together the flour, salt and 1 tablespoon sugar. Make a well in the center and add 3 egg yolks and 1/2 cup ice water. Gradually blend the liquid into the flour mixture until almost smooth. Stir in the plum brandy. Chill for 30 minutes.
 2. Meanwhile, in a wide, shallow bowl, combine the cinnamon with the remaining 1/2 cup sugar. Whip the egg whites to soft peaks. 
 3. Fold the whipped egg whites into the batter. In a heavy saucepan, heat 2 inches of oil over medium-high heat; it's hot enough when it quickly browns a small drop of batter. Coat the plum halves in the batter, then fry in the oil until puffed and golden, turning once. Use a splatter guard to prevent the juices from splattering. Using a slotted spoon, transfer the fritters to the bowl of cinnamon sugar. Roll them in the sugar, then set on a plate lined with paper towels. Eat warm or at room temperature. Makes 12 fritters.

HEADLINE: IN OTHER WORDS

 BODY:
Are Montclair's Children Being Left Behind?
 Educated citizens are the components of every successful nation.
 Most citizens recognize that the United States must improve the quality of its public education. Our national aptitude in mathematics, engineering and science has waned. The grammar and spelling skills of many young and middle-aged people must improve. Without adequate education, millions of American kids confront low-paying jobs and social miseries. 
 Recognizing our nation's diminishing quality of education, the federal government under President George W. Bush established the No Child Left Behind Act of 2001. Leading liberals and conservatives in Congress initially supported the act.
 The act's long-term goal is to have every public-school student pass standardized tests by 2014.
 Accountability is emphasized. In some New Jersey municipalities, there have been shocking lapses in student advancement. School systems in some New Jersey cities were so corrupt and ineffective that the state Department of Education seized control of their administrative offices.
 The intent of the act is to hold governmental employees and school districts responsible for delivering qualified, effective education for young citizens.
 A key shortcoming is insufficient funding for its mandates. While Congress has significantly increased federal funding for education (via federal indebtedness), the total still falls far short of the needed amount. The law places much of its financial onus on states and individual school districts.
 The Montclair School District is not deprived of funds. With a budget of $103 million, Montclair faculty members receive decent wages and guaranteed salary increases, regardless of the private sector's economic plight. The Montclair School District provides benefits, pensions, holidays and vacation amounts that are unrivaled by businesses.
 No Child Left Behind shackles Montclair and other school districts with additional costly mandates. Already burdened with a huge tax to support their public schools, taxpayers must give more of their earnings to pay for expenditures dictated by the act.
 Last week, five of the Montclair School District's 10 eligible schools did not meet No Child Left Behind mandates -- even though the vast majority of students in each school have achieved the criteria.
 Good teachers and administrators can only achieve so much. The studiousness of most students also requires the responsibility of their family members, religious and community leaders and the students themselves.
 There has been a concern, including here in Montclair, that some teachers ''teach to the test,'' rather than imparting in-depth knowledge on core subjects to their students.
 Plenty of other concerns exist about No Child Left Behind.
 There are congressional considerations about eliminating or drastically altering the act, which is slated to be reauthorized in 2008. Accountability, however, must be sustained.
 In the United States, a quality education is essential for national strength and individual success.
 The Montclair Times, Aug. 22

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: A Quick Brunello On the Way to Rome

BYLINE: By LOUISE KRAMER

 BODY:
Getting stuck waiting for a plane is nobody's idea of fun. But Doug Tomlinson, a former management consultant with Deloitte in San Francisco, is doing his best to improve the experience with Vino Volo, a growing chain of airport wine bars.
 The fifth Vino Volo (''wine flight'' in Italian) will open at Kennedy Airport on Sept. 26. The sleek spots offer a respite for oenophiles, with wines by the glass or bottle, small plates of cheese and cured meats, leather chairs and outlets for laptops. 
 After talking himself out of dozens of business ideas over the years, Mr. Tomlinson said he had a light bulb moment in 2003 in a Midwest airport when he longed for a decent glass of wine to celebrate a deal with some colleagues, but had to settle for beer. ''I am a pretty risk-averse guy most of the time,'' he said. ''The unique thing about this is that I wasn't able to talk myself out of it.''
 He took a leave from Deloitte to create Vino Volo and never went back. He got advice and backing from some big names in food and wine, like W. Reed Foster, co-founder of Ravenswood Winery, Paul Clayton, chief executive of Jamba Juice, and John Scharffenberger, the chocolate maker.
 LOUISE KRAMER 
 TIME TO PAY UP? The S.E.C. has announced that Orlando Joseph Jett, once a bond-trading star, lost his appeal of an agency order that he disgorge $8.2 million in bonuses rewarded in connection with a fraudulent trading scheme and that he pay a $200,000 civil penalty.
 A federal district judge in Manhattan recently upheld a March 2004 order by the Securities and Exchange Commission saying that Mr. Jett, a former Kidder, Peabody government bond trader, had booked fake profits of approximately $264 million and had to pay restitution. 
 Federal securities regulators found that while Mr. Jett worked as a trader, managing director and senior vice president of the now-defunct Kidder, he used a loophole in its automated trading records system to book enormous profits, when his trading activities actually lost $75 million. Kidder fired Mr. Jett in 1994 after the scandal came to light. 
 The commission initially sued Mr. Jett more than a decade ago. After losing several rounds in court, he refused to surrender the money. Then, he said he had been denied due process because he never received a copy of a 2004 S.E.C. order. He tried to have the commission's order reviewed by a federal appeals court. But the Sept. 7 ruling in Federal District Court held that Mr. Jett had not filed his appeal within acceptable time limits and that he had to pay.
 Mr. Jett, who works as a money manager at Jett Capital Management, based in Princeton, N.J., did not return a telephone call for comment. ELIZABETH OLSON
 WHAT'S THAT WORD? Robert L. Nardelli had a reputation for unusual pronunciations and word usage when he was chief executive of Home Depot. Now that he is at Chrysler, he is showing every sign of continuing the tradition.
 During a recent speech to the Automotive Press Association, Mr. Nardelli drew smiles when he called Detroit's famed Woodward Avenue ''Wood-ard.'' 
 He stumbled again when he tried to use industry jargon. Speaking of annual sales, he said, ''We're looking at an industry that started the year at about 17 million, right? 16.9, 16.8, 16.6 -- look at the last SAP and it's about 16.2.'' 
 He meant ''SAAR,'' for seasonally adjusted annual rate, the way auto makers project monthly sales over a year's time.
 That's O.K. We couldn't name half the stuff in Aisle 13. MICHELINE MAYNARD
 GREENSPAN'S DEFENSE When the economy starts to flounder, people start pointing fingers -- and right now they are pointing at Alan Greenspan, former Fed chairman. 
 Mr. Greenspan, far more accustomed to encomiums, isn't just rolling over. Taking on critics in an interview tonight on CBS's ''60 Minutes,'' he defends his decisions to handle an earlier economic downturn by lowering interest rates between 2001 and 2004. 
 In excerpts released by CBS, Mr. Greenspan calls his critics ''mistaken.'' The Fed's job was ''to unfreeze the American banking system if we wanted the economy to function,'' he said. ''This required that we keep rates modestly low.''
 Sustained low interest rates fed speculative borrowing, some economists say. That, they say, led to questionable mortgage lending that is reverberating in markets now.
 Mr. Greenspan, who stepped down from the Fed in January 2006, candidly admitted that he did not foresee the impact of subprime lending practices, telling Lesley Stahl on CBS that ''I really didn't get it until very late in 2005 and 2006.''
 Mr. Greenspan will have plenty of opportunity to defend his record. His interview was only one of a series he is giving to publicize his memoir, ''The Age of Turbulence,'' which is to be released tomorrow.
 ELIZABETH OLSON

HEADLINE: An Early Apartment House By the Master of Tuxedo Park

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
QAt 21 East 21st Street, the initials C. M. are over the entrance. I have always wondered whose initials they were. ... Mike Grant, Brooklyn
 A More likely the monogram should be read as M. C., the initials for both Marie and Miers Coryell, the couple who built this unusual apartment house in 1878. 
 It was designed by Bruce Price, who gained fame in the 1880s for the enclave at Tuxedo Park, N.Y. The Coryells gave him one of his first jobs, and he produced this little Queen Anne gem of brick and carved stone, with two picturesque dormers on the sixth floor. 
 It is rare to see an owner's monogram on a building, and rarer still to have the names of the builder -- David H. King Jr. -- plus that of the architect himself, on either side of the date stone, as they are here.
 Little is known about Marie Coryell, but in 1892, The New York Times called Miers Coryell one of the best known experts on marine engines in the country. How the Coryells came to hire Mr. Price, who was then new to New York and just beginning his career, is a mystery, and their decision to build an income-producing property in the form of an upper-middle-class apartment house is very unusual. Such buildings were still rare in New York; the Dakota, for instance, was not even begun until 1880.
 Mr. Price designed a picturesque if ungainly facade, rich in carved detail and peculiar ornamentation. His awkward floor plan shows how new a discipline apartment design was back then. 
 There was one apartment per floor. Mr. Price put the parlor and one bedroom in front, then strung out the dining room, the three main bedrooms and a servant's bedroom back toward the rear of the lot, each facing a mean little courtyard. At the end was the kitchen, and all were connected by a bowling alley of a corridor, perhaps 75 feet long. 
 This was a walk-up, with two circular staircases, a small one in the rear and a larger one in the front. The Coryells lived in the building, as did a doctor and a lawyer.
 Some idea of the building's economic circumstances may be gleaned from a help-wanted ad that someone there placed in The Times in 1881 for ''an excellent cook, who will also wash bed and table linen.''
 In 1890, an ad offered the first-floor apartment for $1,400 a year. The rent also included a storage area and extra servant's room on the sixth floor. 
 Mr. Price was a designer of sparkling ability, and as his career progressed, he was frequently called on for upper-class residences -- at Tuxedo Park, at Bar Harbor, Me., and in similar locales. By the turn of the last century he was getting bigger commissions, and when he died in 1903, at 57, his plans had been accepted for a palace in Tokyo for the crown prince of Japan. 
 But his daughter, Emily, eclipsed his reputation. Under her married name, Emily Post, she wrote ''Etiquette in Society, in Business, in Politics and at Home,'' published in 1922, and it became the last word in manners. 
 Whatever social standing 21 East 21st originally had was long gone by 1953, when its certificate of occupancy showed that it had been turned into a single-room-occupancy hotel. A gut renovation took place about 30 years ago, apparently in 1977.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 23, 2007

 CORRECTION:
The Streetscapes column last Sunday, in a response to a reader's question about the history of 21 East 21st Street, described the original interior of the building incorrectly. It had an elevator. It was not a walk-up.

HEADLINE: Why Haven't Investors Played It Safe With Blue Chips?

BYLINE: By PAUL J. LIM. 
Paul J. Lim is a senior editor at Money magazine. E-mail: fund@nytimes.com

 BODY:
HAVE blue-chip stocks suffered another setback?
 Last year, professional money managers were finally warming up to large-capitalization stocks, after favoring their smaller and sexier small-cap cousins throughout much of this decade. This spring, large-cap stocks started to look even more attractive, thanks to the booming global economy and the falling dollar, which benefit the large caps because big companies tend to do a greater share of their business overseas.
 Then came what was supposed to be the clincher. In July, as market volatility spiked, the consensus view on Wall Street was that investors would finally flock back to large-cap stocks because of the stability and safety that big, industry-leading companies can provide. 
 Well, July came around, and while the smart money said investors would bite, many of them didn't. In fact, nearly $3.1 billion in net new money was pulled from large-cap stock funds in July, according to Citigroup Investment Research and Strategic Insight. In fact, more money was yanked from large-cap stock funds than was pulled from small-cap funds, which had net redemptions of $1.1 billion that month. 
 To be sure, this is only one month's worth of data. And Tobias Levkovich, Citigroup's chief United States equity strategist, points out that large-cap stock funds sit on a bigger mountain of assets to begin with -- so larger outflows aren't necessarily troubling. 
 Still, why did investors flee from -- rather than run to -- the relative safety of blue-chip stocks? 
 One possible explanation is that the recent market sell-off was set off by growing troubles in the mortgage market. And credit troubles clearly affect the financial services sector, which happens to be the biggest sector in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index of blue-chip stocks, representing 20 percent of the benchmark.
 ''To the extent that there are a lot of financials in the large-cap space, and that those financial companies have credit exposure, I think this would retard the development of the case for large-caps,'' said John S. Osterweis, president and chief investment officer for Osterweis Capital Management in San Francisco. 
 Of course, it's not clear cut. 
 For starters, while the financial sector makes up one-fifth of the S.& P. 500, small-cap stocks aren't devoid of exposure to banks and brokers. In fact, 15 percent of the Standard & Poor's 600 index of small stocks is made up of financial services firms.
 And among mutual funds, the gap is even narrower. While the average large-cap value stock fund invests 26.3 percent of its assets in financial companies, small-cap value funds have nearly as much exposure: 22.2 percent, according to Morningstar.
 Also, keep in mind that while many large investment banks like Bear Stearns have garnered big headlines recently because of their exposure to mortgage-backed securities, many of the stocks that were hit hardest recently were small-cap subprime lenders and savings institutions, said Wendell L. Perkins, chief investment officer for Johnson Asset Management in Racine, Wis.
 This may explain why, even with their slightly greater weighting to financial stocks, large-cap stocks fell less than the small-caps when the market began to sink. ''In July, you were much better off in the large caps,'' said Russel Kinnel, director of mutual fund research for the fund tracker Morningstar. 
 The mega-cap Russell Top 50 Index, which tracks the 50 largest domestic stocks, lost only 2 percent of its value in July. By comparison, the Russell 1000 blue-chip index, which includes 950 less gigantic stocks, fell 3.1 percent. The Russell 2000 index of small-cap stocks tumbled 6.8 percent. And the Russell Microcap index, made up of the market's tiniest companies, did the worst as it shed 7 percent of its value.
 Mr. Perkins, who also co-manages the JohnsonFamily Small Cap Value and JohnsonFamily Large Cap Value funds, said blue-chip stocks should continue to hold up well as investors turn their attention away from the immediate financial troubles in the mortgage market to what those financial troubles could mean for the broader economy. Once that happens, it will put even more pressure on the equity markets, which in turn should drive more interest into the large-cap stocks, he said.
 Ernest M. Ankrim, chief investment strategist at the Russell Investment Group in Tacoma, Wash., agrees: ''There's a reasonably strong case for large caps for the remainder of the year and going into 2008.''
 Market strategists point to several factors that should work to the advantage of the blue chips. 
 For starters, many economists now expect the Federal Reserve to cut short-term interest rates, either at the upcoming Federal Open Market Committee meeting this week or sometime later this year. If the Fed trims rates, Mr. Ankrim said that would put even more downward pressure on the dollar. And that, in turn, ''would almost certainly be good for firms with global reach,'' he said. This means the blue chips.
 Furthermore, Mr. Levkovich at Citigroup points out that historically, large-cap stocks tend to outperform during periods of slowing earnings growth and increasing market volatility. 
 EARNINGS for companies in the S.& P. 500 are expected to expand just 4.5 percent in the third quarter, according to Thomson Financial. That's down from 7.9 percent in the first quarter and 10.6 percent late last year. As for volatility, the Chicago Board Options Exchange Volatility Index, or VIX, is now consistently trading above a reading of 20 now, after being in the teens in recent years.
 While these signs are bullish for blue chips, investors must still be judicious when hunting in the large-cap space, said Steven Romick, manager of the FPA Crescent Fund, which invests in stocks of all sizes.
 Mr. Romick noted that while large-cap stocks are cheaper than their small-cap counterparts, ''they're not ridiculously cheaper.'' He added that the recent troubles in the financial services sector show that ''one still has to be quite selective'' even when dealing with the bluest blue-chip stocks.

HEADLINE: All Aboard

BYLINE: By Lawrence H. Silverman. 
Lawrence H. Silverman, a lawyer who was the chairman of the Long Island Rail Road Commuters Council, was a member of the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority from 1996 to 2001.

 BODY:
Huntington
 EVEN with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's recent announcement of possible fare increases, there are hopeful signs for those of us who ride the Long Island Rail Road, which is operated by the authority. 
 For starters, Helena Williams became the new president of the railroad in June. The former deputy county executive in Nassau and president of Long Island Bus from 1993 to 1998, Ms. Williams knows Long Island and its transportation needs. And unlike most of her predecessors, Ms. Williams never worked for a railroad, much less the nation's largest, busiest and most complex commuter railroad -- she's an outsider with no ties to bind her to past practices. She is also a former labor counsel to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, experience that will be critical to her ability to work with the railroad's powerful unions. 
 At her first board meeting of the authority this summer, Ms. Williams made it clear that she would not waste time getting to the bottom of the problems that plague the railroad and announced that she was hiring a consultant, Donald Nelson, a former president of Metro-North Railroad. Mr. Nelson is credited with much of Metro-North's success and its high marks in customer satisfaction. Ms. Williams asked him to conduct a ''state of the system'' analysis of the railroad and come up with a ''blueprint of what are the next steps.'' His report is scheduled to be released next month. 
 It's a pretty good guess that the arrival of Ms. Williams and Mr. Nelson was not celebrated by many Long Island Rail Road employees -- certainly not by the managers who recently acknowledged that they knew for years that dangerous gaps between trains and platforms could be reduced but did nothing about them until a passenger was killed last year at Woodside Station in Queens. 
 Of course, all of this raises the question: Can Mr. Nelson do for Long Island what he did for Metro-North? Probably not. After all, Metro-North passengers enjoy direct service, whereas many of us have to switch at Jamaica Station, where trains must arrive, exchange passengers and depart within a two-minute window. As a result, small delays quickly multiply into big ones. Nor does Metro-North have to compete with other railroads for access to Grand Central Terminal; the Long Island Rail Road shares Pennsylvania Station with New Jersey Transit and Amtrak. 
 Another important difference between the Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North is on the labor front. The relationship between labor and management on the L.I.R.R. is one of the least discussed and yet one of the most important factors affecting its efficiency and the quality of service. In order to achieve anything resembling meaningful and lasting change on the railroad, Ms. Williams and Mr. Nelson must earn the confidence and then the cooperation of managers and the work force. It will not be easy. 
 Many employees' families have worked on the railroad for generations. To them the Long Island Rail Road is not merely a job, it is their life, and their co-workers are their extended family. Promoting workers to management improves morale. Hiring outsiders generally has the opposite effect. 
 When Thomas Prendergast, a former senior vice president of New York City Transit, became president of the Long Island Rail Road in 1994, he tried to change what he repeatedly referred to as the ''culture'' on the railroad. He replaced some department heads with former colleagues from the subway. The results were not pretty: air-conditioning failures, undercarriage fires and breakdowns that reports later found were due to neglected or faulty maintenance. At least partly because of Mr. Prendergast's difficulties with labor and management, riders suffered some of the worst service ever.
 On the Long Island Rail Road, work rule changes intended to promote efficiency and improve service are difficult to achieve. With the right to strike, Long Island Rail Road workers have the power to cripple Long Island's economy, giving them unparalleled leverage in contract negotiations.
 Yet, early indications are that Ms. Williams and Mr. Nelson may be on the right track. Railroad employees have long complained that management does not listen to them. So after observing how railroad managers dealt with a thunderstorm in July that knocked out service on several lines, the next morning, Ms. Williams sat down with them. Together, they came up with ways to better communicate in emergencies and restore service more quickly. And at the next Metropolitan Transportation Authority meeting, Ms. Williams publicly recognized the ''specialized skills'' that enabled workers to get the trains running again.
 If this is the beginning of a sincere effort by Ms. Williams and Mr. Nelson to communicate with workers, their listening tour might be the thing that makes this administration different and provide the catalyst necessary for lasting change on the Long Island Rail Road. Riders can only hope.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
